Beloved Indian YouTube star Narayana Reddy, known for his mega-sized outdoor cooking, has died, his family said. He was 73. In just two years, Reddy built an audience of more than 6 million subscribers on YouTube, where he uploaded videos of himself and his family members cooking vast meals, which ‚Äî along with the proceeds of the channel ‚Äî went to feed local orphans and other underprivileged people living on the outskirts of Hyderabad, in southern Telangana state. "We will continue his work," Reddy's grandnephew Srikanth Reddy told CNN, adding that his great uncle delighted in the positive reaction his videos received around the world.
(üì∏: YouTube/Grandpa Kitchen)

After an 11-day strike, teachers from America‚Äôs third-largest school district have reached a compromise with school officials and will return to their classrooms on Friday, Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot said. The Chicago Teachers Union has been fighting for smaller class sizes, better pay and more staffing. The exact terms of the deal weren't immediately known, but the mayor said both sides agreed to make up five days of school. (üì∏: Scott Heins/Getty)

There are about 2,150 prison inmates in California who are authorized to fight wildfires, and as multiple fires rage across the state, the role these men and women play is coming under renewed scrutiny. While they receive the same entry-level training as the state‚Äôs seasonal firefighters, they are often denied jobs at fire departments because of their felony records. ‚ÄúThese inmates go through the training and then they want to go on and pursue additional training and that door is closed to them,‚Äù says Mark Farouk, a spokesman for California Assemblywoman Eloise Reyes, who earlier this year introduced a bill that seeks to ease restrictions on ex-convicts. (üì∏: Philip Pacheco/Getty Images)

History is made! ‚öæÔ∏è The Washington Nationals have clinched their first ever World Series title after defeating the Houston Astros 6-2 in the deciding Game 7 on Wednesday night at Minute Maid Park. It‚Äôs the first time that the road team has won every game in the World Series. ‚ÄúIt just means that I am part of the greatest team in 2019,‚Äù Nationals starting pitcher Max Scherzer said. ‚ÄúThese guys, they battled. It was stay in the fight, that was our motto. Everybody gave it their all.‚Äù Anthony Rendon and Howie Kendrick homered to power the Nationals, who had finished the regular season as a wild-card team and were not one of the favorites to win the competition. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve come through all year long for us in big ways. They have the knack to stay calm and do what they need to do,‚Äù Nationals Manager Dave Martinez said after the win. (üì∏: @cnnsport via Elsa/Getty Images, Mike Ehrmann/Getty Images)

From inside the Reagan Presidential Library in Southern California, a fast-moving wildfire could be seen inching toward the building. The Easy Fire burned on all sides of the library complex but the buildings were not in imminent danger, fire department officials said. Simi Valley police ordered evacuations of the library, where the former president's Air Force One jet is on display. The complex is also the grave site for the nation's 40th president and first lady Nancy Reagan. (üì∏: Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times/Getty Images)

NASA astronaut Andrew Morgan captured these photos of the smoke from the California wildfires burning north of the Bay Area ‚Äî as seen from the International Space Station. The photos appear to be of the Kincade Fire and possibly another, which are just two of at least 10 wildfires that have prompted evacuations and highway closures throughout California. "Thinking of the people who have lost their homes and the brave first responders on the front lines protecting them,‚Äù Morgan said in a Facebook post. (üì∏: Andrew Morgan/Facebook)

Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è These maps shows new projections for people in coastal areas at risk from flooding as sea levels rise, and the findings nearly triple previous estimates. Hundreds of millions of people worldwide are at risk of losing their homes as entire cities sink under rising seas over the next three decades, according to researchers. The findings were published in the journal Nature Communications.‚Å£
‚Å£
"The results indicate that, yes, a great deal more people are on vulnerable land than we thought," said Benjamin Strauss, one of the study's co-authors and CEO of non-profit organization Climate Central. By 2050, land that is currently home to about 300 million people will fall below the elevation of the average annual coastal flood, meaning those areas could face severe floods at least once a year. By 2100, land that is home to 200 million people could sit permanently below the high tide line, rendering those coastal areas all but unlivable.
(üì∏: Climate Central)

Actor and comedian John Witherspoon, whose hilarious takes on father-figure characters made for iconic scenes in a number of movies and TV shows, died at his home Tuesday, a family spokesperson told CNN. He was 77. He was arguably best known for playing Ice Cube's dad in the "Friday" film series. "I'm devastated over the passing of John Witherspoon," Ice Cube wrote on Twitter. "Life won't be as funny without him." Born in Detroit, Witherspoon kicked off his career as a stand-up comedian and made his television debut in the 1970s, appearing in shows including the detective series "Barnaby Jones." (üì∏: Jeffrey Ufberg/WireImage/Getty Images)

In a stunning reversal, the NCAA Board of Governors on Tuesday voted unanimously to allow student athletes to be paid for the use of their name, image and likeness once its three divisions decide on rules for such opportunities. "We must embrace change to provide the best possible experience for college athletes," said Michael Drake, chair of the board for the NCAA, which governs major college athletics. The vote came after California passed a Fair Pay to Play Act, which would allow the state‚Äôs college athletes to sign endorsement deals and licensing contracts when it goes into effect in 2023. The NCAA initially pushed back on the California law, saying it would give those schools an unfair recruiting advantage and ‚Äúlead to the professionalization of college sports." (üì∏: Jae C. Hong/AP/File)

When he couldn‚Äôt find wheelchair-inclusive Halloween costumes in stores, Tom Hardy decided to build one himself for his son Tommy. That was seven years ago, and each year Hardy‚Äôs creations have grown more elaborate. This year, 15-year-old Tommy, who has cerebral palsy, autism and is non-verbal, is going trick-or-treating in style in a custom Air Force fighter jet. ‚ÄúNo kid is looking at him like he's in a wheelchair," Hardy told CNN. ‚ÄúIt's an amazing feeling for him, just to be seen as a typical kid.‚Äù For less than $100, Hardy and two buddies spent 100 hours crafting Tommy‚Äôs jet out of wood. He's previously transformed Tommy's chair into a "Game of Thrones" dragon and an X-wing from "Star Wars.‚Äù And while some major retailers now offer decorative wheelchair covers for children, progress Hardy welcomes, he says he won‚Äôt quit dreaming up stuff you can‚Äôt find in stores. (üì∏: Tom Hardy)

A twin-engine plane crashed into a suburban home in New Jersey on Tuesday, sparking a house fire, authorities said. The Federal Aviation Administration and the National Transportation Safety Board are investigating the crash of the Cessna 414. (üì∏: Michael Yonone/Facebook)

Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è Spurred by historic winds, firefighters in California are battling more than a dozen blazes across the state, including the Tick and Getty Fires in Southern California and the Kincade Fire in Northern California. The fires have displaced hundreds of thousands of people and caused power outages in parts of the state. Scientists say climate change is a factor in the increasing size of California‚Äôs wildfires over the past 50 years. ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt believe climate change is happening, talk to a firefighter,‚Äù Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti told CNN on Monday. (üì∏: John Edelson/AFP/Getty Images, Philip Pacheco/AFP/Getty Images, Justin Sullivan/Getty Images, Neal Waters/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images)

There are good dogs -- and then there are hero dogs. US President Donald Trump said that this dog, part of the operation that resulted in the death of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi over the weekend, was injured while chasing Baghdadi down a dead-end tunnel. It is believed to have been sent down the tunnel after it was feared that Baghdadi was wearing a suicide vest. Baghdadi was indeed wearing a suicide vest and detonated it in the tunnel, killing himself and three children. Trump declassified a photo of the K-9, tweeting, "We have declassified a picture of the wonderful dog (name not declassified) that did such a GREAT JOB in capturing and killing the Leader of ISIS, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi!" The hound, part of the Army Delta force, which executed the raid, was believed to have been injured from an electrocution and is recovering, a US defense official said.

A lost 13th-century masterpiece that had been hanging in an elderly French woman‚Äôs kitchen was auctioned on Sunday in France for $26.8 million. The unsuspecting owner kept the Cimabue piece, titled ‚ÄúChrist Mocked,‚Äù above a hot plate used for cooking food, according to AFP. One artist expert said the piece, which was probably part of a triptych made in 1280, is the first ever Cimabue painting to be auctioned. (üì∏: Philipe Lopez/AFP/Getty Images)

How‚Äôs this for spooky? ‚òÄÔ∏èüéÉ@NASA on Sunday shared a photo on social media of the sun looking a lot like a giant, flaming jack-o‚Äô-lantern. The space agency, which captured the image on October 8, 2014, said the face is the result of active regions of the sun burning more brightly than others.

A bus was stopped at a red light Monday morning in Pittsburgh when a sinkhole opened up beneath it, swallowing the back end, Port Authority of Allegheny County officials said. The bus driver and one passenger were on board and both were able to exit safely, though the passenger was being treated for minor injuries, according to the Port Authority.
(üì∏: Pittsburgh Public Safety Department)

Lyft is offering riders free or discounted rides to job interviews and during the first three weeks of employment through a new initiative üöó The Jobs Access Program looks to close the transportation gap in low-income communities, the rideshare company said, and it'll be offered in more than 35 markets in the US and Canada. "For the unemployed, reliable transportation to a job interview or to the first few weeks of work can mean the difference between successful, long-term employment and lost opportunities," Lyft said.
(üì∏: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

Rainbow colors üåà filled the streets in Taipei as people celebrated the first pride parade since same-sex marriage was legalized in Taiwan. In May, a landmark decision made the self-ruled island the first place in Asia to pass gay marriage legislation. (üì∏: Sam Yeh/Getty Images/AFP)

Fur is on its way out at Macy's Inc. The retail giant announced Tuesday that it would stop selling mink, fox, sable and other fur products by February 2021 at its Macy's and Bloomingdale's stores, as well as its outlets. The decision comes as the fashion world is reconsidering its use of fur products. Gucci, Chanel and Burberry have all gone fur-free in recent years. (üì∏: Getty Images)

Instagram banned all face filters associated with plastic surgery earlier this month in an effort to create a healthier experience for users. ‚ÄúWe want [augmented reality] effects to be a positive experience for people,‚Äù a spokesperson said. However, some critics say the ban isn‚Äôt enough. ‚ÄúBanning surgery filters won‚Äôt help unless the app is working to make sure that users see a range of beauty standards,‚Äù said Lily Chumley, a media professor at NYU. ‚ÄúIt might be more effective to work on changing the algorithms that push images to viewers.‚Äù (üì∏: @francoisssagat)

New Jersey wants to revoke the liquor license at one of President Donald Trump‚Äôs golf clubs in response to a 2015 incident during which the club allegedly overserved a guest who later pleaded guilty to vehicular homicide. A letter from the state‚Äôs Division of Alcohol Beverage Control to the club said that revocation of the liquor license was a "routine enforcement action‚Äù of liquor licensing laws. (üì∏: Brendan Smialowski/AFP/Getty Images)

A Hong Kong businessman set a new record for the city when he sold a 135-square-foot parking spot for a whopping $969,000 to an unidentified buyer, according to the South China Morning Post. The spot is in front of The Center, a 79-floor steel office tower in the city‚Äôs busy Central neighborhood. The previous record-holder for most expensive parking space in the city was a $760,000 spot in front of a Kowloon luxury apartment building in 2018. It‚Äôs not just parking spaces that are expensive in Hong Kong ‚Äî the annual Mercer Cost of Living Index named Hong Kong the most expensive city in the world for residents in 2018 and 2019. (üì∏: Getty Images/ Didier Marti)

Before New York‚Äôs Central Park was built, a predominantly African American community was forced to move in 1857 to make room for it. Now, a monument is being made to commemorate Seneca Village, which was New York‚Äôs first free black community. The monument will showcase three members of the Lyons family, who were property owners in the village and ran an Underground Railroad station, according to Mayor Bill DeBlasio‚Äôs office. (üì∏: New York Public Library Digital Collections)

Students at Jacksboro Elementary School in Tennessee will have food to eat for the next year thanks to Jennifer Lopez and her fianc√© Alex Rodriguez. The couple gave a generous donation after seeing an emotional Facebook post from teacher Brooke Goins about having to buy a student food. Lopez and Rodriguez connected with Goins and her class via FaceTime to share the good news. "Everyone should have access to delicious, nutritious food. This was my favorite moment of the month and it's one of the best things we've been able to do," Lopez wrote on Instagram. (üì∏: Andrew Toth/Getty Images)

Former Presidents Barack Obama and Bill Clinton hugged during the funeral service honoring the late Rep. Elijah Cummings on Friday. Both men gave moving speeches at the service in Baltimore. ‚ÄúI love every minute I ever spent with him, every conversation we ever had,‚Äù Clinton said. ‚ÄúHe was never complacent, for he knew that without clarity of purpose and a steadfast faith and a dogged determination demanded by our liberty, the promise of this nation could wither,‚Äù Obama said. (üì∏: Julio Cortez/Getty Images)

A firefighter climbed over a gate while fighting the Tick Fire in Canyon County, California. The blaze, which broke out north of Los Angeles on Thursday, forced thousands of residents to evacuate their homes, fire officials said. The cause was unknown. (üì∏: Mario Tama/Getty Images)

Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è Offshore wind power has the capacity to meet all of the world‚Äôs electricity needs, according to a report from the Paris-based International Energy Agency. The agency described its work as ‚Äúthe most comprehensive global study‚Äù of offshore wind ever, an effort that involved analyzing hundreds of thousands of miles of coastline. ‚ÄúOffshore wind currently provides just 0.3% of global power generation, but its potential is vast,‚Äù Faith Birol, the executive director of the IEA, said. ‚ÄúMore and more of that potential is coming within reach, but much work remains to be done by governments and industry for it to become a mainstay.‚Äù (üì∏: Paul Ellis/AFP/Getty Images)

Alexandria Abukaram, a junior at Sylvania Northview High School in Ohio, knew something was wrong when she looked up at the board at the district cross country meet and saw that her name and time for the 5K race were not listed. The 16-year-old soon learned she'd been disqualified because her hijab didn't conform to uniform regulations. "It was like your worst nightmare to have to compete and then find out that you got disqualified and it's because of something that you love," said Abukaram, whose unofficial time at the meet marked a personal best. "Why should you have to sacrifice your religion and a part of who you are to run, to do another thing that you're very passionate about?" The Ohio High School Athletic Association said in response that runners with religious headwear need a waiver to participate.
(üì∏: Zobaida S Falah/Facebook)

Today was the last day ever that climbing was allowed at Uluru, the sacred red rock in Australia's Northern Territory. Crowds flocked to the site, once also known as Ayers Rock, to make a final ascent, despite longstanding requests not to climb by Uluru's traditional owners: the local Anangu Aboriginal people. Climbing the rock is banned starting October 26. The decision to end climbing at Uluru, which was added to the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites in 1987, was made out of respect for the Anangu people. Safety has also been a concern: Uluru is taller than the Eiffel Tower and can be quite dangerous for inexperienced climbers, with people previously being injured or worse. (üì∑ SAEED KHAN/AFP via Getty Images)

Congressional leaders honored the late Rep. Elijah Cummings on Thursday as his body lay in state at the US Capitol. Cummings, a longtime Maryland Democrat and key figure leading investigations into President Trump, died last week at the age of 68. (üì∏: Bloomberg/Getty Images, Mandel Ngan/Getty Images)

The PACT Act ‚Äî which stands for Preventing Animal Cruelty and Torture ‚Äî was unanimously approved by the House on Tuesday. The bipartisan act was introduced by Florida congressmen Ted Deutch (left) and Vern Buchanan (right), pictured above in July with a very good dog üê∂ ‚ÄúThe torture of innocent animals is abhorrent and should be punished to the fullest extent of the law,‚Äù Buchanan said. ‚ÄúPassing the PACT Act sends a strong message that this behavior will not be tolerated.‚Äù The measure must now pass the Senate. (üì∏: CQ-Roll Call Group/Getty Images)

Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is a pop culture icon, a cancer survivor, a feminist trailblazer and now, the recipient of the Berggruen Prize for Philosophy & Culture. The 86-year-old was given the award ‚Äî which will give $1 million to the nonprofit of her choosing ‚Äî  for her contributions to social justice and general equality, the prize jury announced Wednesday. ‚ÄúBy grit and determination, brains, courage, compassion and a fiery commitment to justice, Ruth Bader Ginsburg rose from modest beginnings to become one of the most respected, and most beloved, jurists of our time,‚Äù prize founder Nicolas Berggruen said. Oh, and she still does push-ups every day. (üì∏: Allison Shelley/Getty Images)

About two dozen House Republicans on Wednesday stormed a closed-door deposition to rail against the Democratic-led impeachment inquiry. The chaotic scene, with Republicans flouting House rules to make a political point, represented a new and more confrontational phase of the GOP attack on House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff and the impeachment investigation. ‚ÄúIt was closest thing I‚Äôve seen around here to mass civil unrest as a member of Congress,‚Äù said one source in the room.

Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è The Russian Navy first spotted the five new islands in 2016 using satellite imagery, but only confirmed and mapped them in recent months during an expedition to the site, Russian officials said Tuesday.  The discovery follows a similar one made in January, when glaciers in the Canadian Arctic melted enough to reveal land that had been hidden for at least 40,000 years. Scientists warn that emerging islands aren‚Äôt flukes, but rather the direct result of the growing #climatecrisis as the Arctic undergoes a mass melting of glaciers and sea ice. (üì∏: DigitalGlobe via Getty Images)

Always says it's removing the Venus symbol ‚ôÄÔ∏è
historically used to represent the female sex, from the packaging of it menstruation products to be inclusive of transgender and nonbinary customers after transgender activists and allies began speaking out ‚Äî arguing that not all people who menstruate are women and that not all women menstruate. This is the latest in a series of actions companies and governments are taking to affirm the identities of transgender people as transgender equality activism surges.
(üì∏: Igor Golovniov/SOPA Images/Getty Images)

üéÉ If you thought your Halloween pumpkin carving was impressive, this Tennessee farmer might just have beaten you. Not only did Justin Ownby grow a 910-pound pumpkin, he turned his giant gourd into a water-worthy boat. Justin has spent four years trying to reach his goal of growing a 1,000 pound pumpkin -- although he fell short this year, he managed to hollow out the prodigious plant and take it for a spooky sail in his pond. His wife, Christin, posted videos of his pumpkin paddle to Facebook -- including the moment when Justin went down with his ship after attempting to stand up in the vessel. Christin told CNN that her husband isn't going to stop growing giant pumpkins any time soon, and that "he is hoping to break the 1,000 pound mark next year." (üì∏: Christin Ownby)

Aiden Jaquez began running half marathons at age 6 so he could have shiny medals just like his grandma. But after Aiden learned he could earn the world record for youngest person to run a half marathon in all 50 states, he set out on a mission. Last weekend, 11-year-old Aiden reached his goal after completing a half marathon in Iowa, the final state on his list. Aiden‚Äôs family say he‚Äôs the youngest ever to achieve the feat, but it could take several months to be verified by Guinness. (üì∏: Kathleen Taylor)

The anonymous senior Trump administration official whose 2018 New York Times op-ed was called treasonous by President Trump has written a new book about Trump titled ‚ÄúA Warning‚Äù that will be published next month. CNN has exclusively obtained a cover of the book, which has been a closely guarded secret and will be released November 19 by Twelve, a division of the Hachette Book Group. The author, who penned the Times op-ed titled ‚ÄúI Am Part of the Resistance Inside the Trump Administration,‚Äù will remain anonymous, and sources familiar with the book tell CNN that ‚Äúelaborate precautions have been taken to protect the author‚Äôs identity.‚Äù

Push-ups and planks ‚Äî "both front and side" ‚Äî are a regular part of Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's workout routine, which she kept up even while she being treated for pancreatic cancer. The 86-year-old justice told an audience at Berkeley Law that she never stopped exercising after her fourth cancer diagnosis, and that compared with six months ago she's feeling "very well." In August, Ginsburg said the tumor had been treated "definitively."

Same-sex marriage and abortion will be legalized in Northern Ireland. The changes were imposed by lawmakers in UK Parliament after Northern Ireland's executive body collapsed around three years ago. Many campaigners posted videos on social media of the countdown to midnight as they celebrated the restrictive abortion and same-sex marriage laws coming to an end. "I am thrilled that finally my friends and colleagues can marry without it being a crime in this country," one told CNN. "I am thrilled that women now have the choice with what they can do with their own bodies." Less pleased was Northern Ireland's Democratic Union Party leader, Arlene Foster, who said, "it is a very sad day."

Four players from a girls high school varsity soccer team in Vermont were recently penalized for peeling off their jerseys during a match to reveal a hidden message on their shirts: #EQUALPAY. The move was a nod to some players on the US women‚Äôs national soccer team who have campaigned for equal pay. Despite the penalty, the girls‚Äô message has spread far and wide ‚Äî including to former USWNT player Brandi Chastain, who tweeted her support for the team on Saturday. The girls team is selling the shirts for $25, and men are invited to pay an extra 16% to represent the wage gap, according to a co-captain. (üì∏: Kate Sheeser)

A school in India has apologized after photos emerged of students wearing cardboard boxes on their heads during an exam to discourage cheating. The Bhagat Pre-University College in India's southwestern Karnataka state implemented a trial run of the new measure last Wednesday. The front of the boxes had been cut out to allow students to see their desks and exam sheets, but the boxes restricted their peripheral vision. After a member of staff posted the photos on Facebook, the measure received widespread criticism on social media. S. Suresh Kumar, the state's education minister described the school's practice as "unacceptable." "Nobody has any right to treat anybody more so students like animals," he said. "This (perversion) will be dealt with aptly." (üì∏: Bhagat Pre-University College)

Archaeologists uncovered more than 20 ancient Egyptian coffins in the city of Luxor this week, according to Egypt‚Äôs Ministry of Antiquities. The sarcophagi were found spread out over two levels of a large tomb, and still featured engravings and colors. Authorities described the discovery as ‚Äúone of the largest and most important discoveries to have been announced in the past few years.‚Äù (üì∏: Ministry of Antiquities)

The Barbie Malibu Dreamhouse is no longer just plastic playset, it‚Äôs available to rent. For just $60 a night on Airbnb, one lucky Barbie fan and up to three friends will be the first-ever guests at this glamourous and very, very pink mansion. Highlights of the stay will include riding a hot pink slide from the balcony to the infinity pool, and meeting world-class fencing champion Ibtihaj Muhammad, who has a Barbie in her likeness, for one-on-one fencing lessons. The two-night special, which is in honor of the Barbie brand‚Äôs 60th anniversary, will be available to book starting October 23 at 11 am PT. (üì∏: Courtesy Airbnb)

Twin-ception üë∂üë∂üë©üë© When identical twin girls Addison and Emma were born last month, they were greeted in the delivery room by a pair of identical twin nurses. Tori Howard and Tara Drinkard have worked at Piedmont Athens Regional for years, but the pair had never worked the delivery room together until that day. "(Tara and Tori) have become our friends," the newborns‚Äô father said. "I look forward to letting the girls know about this one day, and hopefully they'll get to meet them and keep carrying this thing on." (üì∏: Piedmont Athens Regional)

The Tasmanian tiger, a large striped carnivore, is believed to have gone extinct over 80 years ago ‚Äî but newly released Australian government documents show sightings have been reported as recently as two months ago üëÄ The Tasmanian tiger, or thylacine, pictured above in a museum in 2002, was native to Tasmania and the Australian mainland. The last known thylacine died in captivity in 1936, and there is no hard evidence to support the its survival. However, regular claims of unsubstantiated sightings have given the marsupial a Loch Ness Monster-type status in Tasmania. (üì∏: Torsten Blackwood/AFP/AFP/Getty Images)

‚û°Ô∏è Follow @ontheroad2020 ‚û°Ô∏è Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez delivered an impassioned speech as she officially endorsed Sen. Bernie Sanders for President at a rally in New York on Saturday. ‚ÄúWhen I was a waitress and when it was time for me to graduate college with student debt, Bernie Sanders was one of the only ones that said no person should be graduating with life-crushing debt at the start of their lives,‚Äù the congresswoman said.

Sanders thanked Ocasio-Cortez during his speech, saying ‚Äúit is hard to believe the degree to which she has transformed politics in America.‚Äù

Former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, have been married for 26,765 days as of Thursday ‚Äî  that‚Äôs more than 75 years ‚Äî making them the longest-married presidential couple. The Carters wed in 1946, when he was 21 and she was 18. The record was previously held by the late George H.W. Bush and Barbara Bush. (üì∏: Getty Images)

Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è The western South Atlantic humpback whale nearly went extinct in the 1950s after centuries of whaling. But thanks to conservation efforts, their population has soared to an estimated 25,000, according to a new study. Alex Zerbini, one of the study‚Äôs authors, said the findings showed it was possible to bring severely depleted populations back from the brink. About 1 million of the planet‚Äôs 8 million species are threatened with extinction by humans, according to a landmark UN report published in May. (üì∏: L. Candisani/Courtesy Instituto Aqualie)

These women just made history. Three astronauts, Jessica Meir and Christina Koch, and Stephanie Wilson embarked on a relatively routine repair mission that nonetheless symbolized one giant leap for women in the space program üöÄ Meir and Koch ventured outside the International Space Station for the first ever all-female spacewalk, while Wilson spoke to them from Mission Control back in Houston. ‚ÄúThis is just us doing our job,‚Äù said Meir. ‚ÄúAt the same time, we recognize that it is a historic achievement and we want to give credit to the women who came before us. We have followed in their footsteps to get where are today.‚Äù (üì∏: @nasa, @iss)

Six-time NBA champion and Hornets owner Michael Jordan this week unveiled the first of two medical clinics he has funded in Charlotte, North Carolina. The facility, which opened Thursday, offers care to Charlotte residents, including underinsured and uninsured patients. ‚ÄúAs you can see, it‚Äôs a very emotional thing for me to be able to give back to a community that‚Äôs supported me over the years,‚Äù he said with tears on his face. (üì∏: Novant Health)

Smoke darkened skies across Lebanon on Friday as economic protests entered a second day. Thousands took to the streets to rail against government efforts to impose new taxes, including a charge on WhatsApp that was later rescinded. Protesters are calling for the resignation of the government and the removal of a political ruling class they accuse of being corrupt and incompetent. ‚ÄúThe country needs to be paralyzed," one protester said. "We tried to protest peacefully‚Ä¶None of it worked. Either we all live peacefully, or no one does.‚Äù (üì∏: Hassan Ammar/AP; Anwar Amro/AFP/Getty Images; Joseph Eid/AFP/Getty Images; Mahmoud Zayyat/AFP/Getty Images)

The seat belonging to the late Rep. Elijah Cummings has been draped in black. Cummings, the chairman of the House Oversight and Reform Committee, died at the age of 68 from "complications concerning longstanding health challenges," his office said.
(üì∏: Olivier Douliery/AFP/Getty Images)

About 25,000 teachers went on strike Thursday in Chicago, the third-largest school district in the US, prompting the city to cancel classes for more than 300,000 students. The Chicago Teachers Union‚Äôs demands reflect what teachers across the US have been clamoring for: more resources, more support staff and better pay. ‚ÄúOur students deserve smaller class sizes. They deserve nurses. They deserve social workers. They deserve bilingual educators,‚Äù special education teacher Linda Perales said. At Thursday‚Äôs marches, many called out Mayor Lori Lightfoot, who has said the city can‚Äôt afford all of the teachers‚Äô demands. (üì∏: @ohjill/Jillian Nolke, @omarcnn/Omar Jimenez, Sarah Howland)

Rep. Elijah Cummings, a powerful Democrat and key figure leading investigations into President Donald Trump, has died at age 68. As chairman of the House Oversight Committee, Cummings oversaw multiple investigations into the Trump administration and often clashed publicly with the President. The longtime congressman was known as a tireless defender of his Maryland district, which included his hometown of Baltimore, and became a leading voice among African American lawmakers on Capitol Hill. Tap the link in our bio for more on Cummings' legacy.

In an image released by the White House, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi stands with her finger pointed at President Trump during a meeting in which the President ‚Äúhad a meltdown,‚Äù according to Democratic leaders who were present. "He was insulting, particularly to the speaker. She kept her cool completely, but he called her a third-rate politician," Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer told reporters after the meeting. Tap the link on our bio for more on the tense exchange.
(üì∏: White House Photo)

Rep. Elijah Cummings died Thursday morning at age 68.
The Democratic congressman has represented Maryland's 7th Congressional District since 1996 and served as the chairman of the House Oversight and Reform Committee, which is one of the committees involved in the impeachment inquiry of President Donald Trump. He died of "complications concerning longstanding health challenges," his office said.
The son of former sharecroppers, Cummings was born in Baltimore in 1951 and graduated from Baltimore City College High School in 1969. In 1996, he was first elected to the US Congress. Cummings was reelected last year with 76% of the vote. (üì∏: Chip Somodevilla / Getty Images)

California Gov. Gavin Newsom signed legislation Friday that will make it illegal to sell, donate or manufacture new fur products in the state. The bill, authored by state assemblymaker Laura Friedman, will go into effect on January 1, 2020, and applies to all new clothing, handbags, shoes and other items made with fur. (üì∏: Richard Vogel/AP)

Photographer @garyhershorn snapped this image of the moon rising over New York on Tuesday evening üåïüèô Hershorn wrote on Instagram that he took the picture of the Manhattan skyline from Green Brook Township, New Jersey, using a telephoto lens.

NASA just revealed the spacesuit to be worn by the first woman to land on the moon üöÄüë©‚ÄçüöÄ The space agency's Artemis program is focused on sending two astronauts ‚Äî one male, one female ‚Äî to moon's surface by 2024, a process that required an upgrade to the spacesuits worn by Apollo-era astronauts in the 1960s and 70s. NASA said it used 3D scanning to design a closer fit for individual astronauts, giving them more mobility while still protecting them from radiation, extreme temperatures, and micrometeoroids.

Click the link in bio to read about all the new features.
(üì∏: @NASA)

North Korea released new photos of leader Kim Jong Un riding a white horse on a snowy mountain. Why exactly? Mount Paektu is one of the country's most important cultural and geological sites. North Korean state propaganda glorifies the Kim family for their "Mount Paektu bloodline," which is said to be a noble lineage tied to the ancient kings of the Korean Peninsula. (üì∏: KCNA)

Chloe Newman lost her right leg when she was a baby, so when Mattel released a Barbie with a prosthetic leg, she wanted to give them to kids just like her. The 18-year-old and her family donated about 430 Barbies on Monday to Shriners Hospital for Children in Springfield, Massachusetts. "I think that they would feel better about themselves maybe, or at least that's what I'm hoping that they would say. 'Oh that's really cool, they're making a Barbie like me, so why should I be ashamed of myself if there's now toys like me,'" Newman told CNN affiliate WWLP.
(üì∏: Shriners Hospital for Children Springfield and @mattel)

A new study suggests the climate crisis is increasing the risk of Ebola spreading beyond current outbreak areas in West Africa, and potentially hitting China, Russia, India, Europe and the United States by 2070. The study cited several factors contributing to the risk, including changes to animal habitats that increase the rate of animal-to-human communication of the deadly disease.
(üì∏: John Wessels/AFP/Getty Images)

At least 72 people were confirmed dead on Tuesday after Typhoon Hagibis slammed into Japan's Izu Peninsula, southwest of Tokyo, over the weekend. Thousands of residents were still without power or water Tuesday, as evening temperatures hovered around 59 degrees Fahrenheit, according to public broadcaster NHK. Japanese officials said about 110,000 search and rescue forces were deployed.
(üì∏: Carl Court/Getty Images, Eugene Hoshiko/AP, Yohei Kanasashi/AP, STR/Jiji Press/AFP/Getty Images and The Yomiuri Shimbun/AP)

A new law in California guarantees all students will receive lunch at school even if their parents or guardians have not paid their meal fees. It also ensures "that the pupil is not shamed or treated differently from other pupils." Gov. Gavin Newsom said he was inspired by a 9-year-old who used his allowance ‚Äî all $74.80 of it ‚Äî to pay off his third grade class's lunch debt. "He showed how at many schools across the country, students whose parents are not able to pay for their lunch are given a cheaper, 'alternative' lunch that causes them to stick out from their peers," the governor said. "I want to thank Ryan for his empathy and his courage in bringing awareness to this important issue." A survey by the School Nutrition Association found that three-fourths of school districts reported having unpaid student meal debt at the end of the 2016-2017 school year.

Vandals threw red paint on statues of Christopher Columbus in San Francisco and Providence, Rhode Island, on Monday, the US federal holiday honoring the Italian explorer. The holiday has come under intense scrutiny in recent years, with historians and activists pointing to Columbus' role in colonizing North America, killing native people and spreading slavery. Several US cities and state governments have opted to rename the holiday "Indigenous Peoples' Day" to honor indigenous history and culture.
(üì∏: WJAR and KRON)

Marine veteran Travis Snyder left his job, sold his car, got rid of his apartment and hiked 810 miles around Lake Michigan ‚Äî all to raise awareness for veteran suicide prevention. Snyder says he began the 42-day journey because of his personal tie to the issue. In April, a friend from Snyder‚Äôs unit in Afghanistan died by suicide, stunning Snyder and his friends. ‚ÄúI guess you could say it was a wake-up call to check in on each other a little more often,‚Äù he told CNN. Within weeks of starting, Snyder‚Äôs mission was met with an outpouring of love, with some people even joining him for stretches of the hike. In Snyder‚Äôs final post from the trek, he wrote, ‚ÄúTogether, we will make a tremendous difference.‚Äù (üì∏:Travis Snyder)

Order in the dream house! Mattel just unveiled its 2019 Barbie Career of the Year Doll: Barbie Judge Doll. The company chose a judge after learning that only 33% of sitting US state judges are women, a Barbie spokesperson told USA TODAY. The Judge Barbie announcement came soon after Mattel released a line of racially diverse and gender-inclusive dolls. (üì∏: Mattel)

New Orleans Saints linebacker Demario Davis says he won‚Äôt have to pay a $7,017 fine for wearing a ‚ÄúMan of God‚Äù headband, so he‚Äôs donating the money, and more, to his hometown hospital. The NFL prohibits players from ‚Äúwearing, displaying or otherwise conveying personal messages‚Äù during game day events unless they are approved by the league. Davis announced Tuesday that he won his appeal and that he‚Äôd be giving the fine money, as well as more than $30,000 he raised selling the headbands online, to St. Dominic Hospital in Jackson, Mississippi. (üì∏: Stephen Lew/Icon Sportswire/Getty Images)

Eugene Bullard, who was the first African American pilot to fly in combat, has been memorialized with a statue at an aviation museum in Georgia. Bullard, whose father was born into slavery, flew for France during World War I. His distant cousin, Harriett Bullard White, told CNN she wept with joy as she placed a wreath at the statue during a ceremony on Wednesday. "All my life I'd known how great he was. Of course, no one else knew who he is," White said. "He's an American hero and someone all Americans should know about." (üì∏: Bob Andres/AP)

Danny McDaniel was kayaking off the coast of California last weekend when a shark bit into his boat, then quickly released it and swam away. After inspecting his kayak, McDaniel found that the shark left behind two teeth and a massive jaw imprint. Scientists who reviewed the size of the shark‚Äôs teeth estimated that the animal was probably between 17 and 20 feet long. "It is pretty amazing and encouraging that such large animals are still able to exist out there with fishing activities and human encroachment and environmental change," said one scientist. (üì∏:Danny McDaniel)

Kenya's Eliud Kipchoge is the first person ever to run a marathon in under two hours. üèÜ
In Vienna, the 34-year-old ran the 26.2 miles in 1 hour, 59 minutes and 40 seconds ‚Äî an achievement considered one of the ultimate milestones in athletic performance. "I am the happiest man," Kipchoge said, adding that he hopes to have inspired many that "no human is limited."
Despite the achievement, the milestone won't count as a world record. During the race, Kipchoge followed behind a car ‚Äî a condition not allowed under IAAF sanctions ‚Äî and was assisted by an army of 30 pacemakers. In 2018, Kipchoge set the marathon world record, winning the Berlin race in 2 hours, 1 minute and 39 seconds. "Berlin is running and breaking a world record," said Kipchoge. "Vienna is running and making history ‚Äî like the first man to go to the moon." (üì∏: Herbert Neubauer / APA/AFP/Getty Images)

Follow ‚û°Ô∏è@cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è The company International Airlines Group, which owns British Airways, Aer Lingus and Iberia, announced on Thursday that it will remove or offset all carbon emissions from its fleet of over 570 aircraft by 2050. IAG said it would replace older aircraft, invest in sustainable jet fuel and develop technology that removes CO2 from the atmosphere as part of the pledge. Its flagship carrier, British Airways, will also offset all carbon emissions produced by its domestic flights starting next year by investing in solar energy products and planting trees in South America, Africa and Asia. (üì∏: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg/Getty Images)

A snakehead fish, which is an invasive fish species that can breathe air and survive on land, was found in Georgia for the first time this month. Officials are warning anyone who comes into contact with the species to kill it immediately. The long, thin fish are considered dangerous, and have a dark brown blotchy appearance and can grow up to three feet in length. (üì∏: Steve Ruark/AP)

An all-female Delta team flew 120 girls to NASA last week for International Girls in Aviation Day ‚úàÔ∏è The flight from Salt Lake City to Houston had female pilots, flight crew, ramp agents, gate agents, and women giving instructions from the control tower. The girls, who were all 12- to 18-year-old STEM students, spent the day at NASA‚Äôs Mission Control and met with astronaut and aerospace engineer Jeanette Epps. (üì∏: Delta)

Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed has been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his role in ending the 20-year war between Ethiopia and Eritrea. The conflict, which was over disputed border territory, came at a huge financial and human cost to both countries. The 43-year-old also recently won plaudits for his role in helping to broker a power-sharing deal in neighboring Sudan, after a political crisis that led to the arrest of Omar al-Bashir, the country's ruler for almost three decades. "As Prime Minister, Abiy Ahmed has sought to promote reconciliation, solidarity and social justice," said Berit Reiss-Andersen, the Chair of the Norwegian Nobel Committee, at the announcement in Oslo, adding that she hopes the prize can "strengthen Prime Minister Ahmed in his important work." Photo: Monirul Bhuiyan/Getty Images

The man who will be Montgomery, Alabama‚Äôs first African American mayor wants his tenure to signal a new era for his 200-year-old city. ‚ÄúWe want to be seen as a part of the New South,‚Äù Steven Reed told @alisyncamerota on @newdayCNN after his historic win in Tuesday's mayoral runoff. ‚ÄúWe want to turn the page and change the narrative, and that‚Äôs what this election was about.‚Äù

Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è Extinction Rebellion protesters demanding action on climate change on Thursday blocked traffic in New York‚Äôs Times Square, attempted to shut down London‚Äôs City Airport and protested in Trafalgar Square in the British capital. One activist even climbed on top of a plane on the runway as part of a series of protests that the group says will be happening through Saturday at City Airport. Extinction Rebellion recently kicked off a series of coordinated protests called #InternationalRebellion, with demonstrations expected in 60 cities worldwide. (üì∏: @pgrotsch/Twitter, @Dawn9090/Twitter, Isabel Infantes/AFP/Getty)

Iran‚Äôs World Cup qualifier against Cambodia on Thursday was a landmark moment for the country, as women were allowed to enter the stadium for the first time in decades ‚öΩÔ∏è Iran‚Äôs ban on women visiting sports stadiums was not written into law but was put in place shortly after the 1979 Islamic Revolution. However, following pressure from human rights group Amnesty International and soccer‚Äôs world governing body FIFA, Iran agreed to partially lift the restriction. While Thursday's game marks a step forward, Human Rights Watch called the cap of 4,600 female fans "discriminatory, deceptive, and dangerous." (üì∏: AFP via Getty Images)

The DC Council, the legislative branch of the city of Washington, approved an emergency measure to rename this Monday‚Äôs Columbus Day ‚ÄúIndigenous Peoples‚Äô Day.‚Äù But it‚Äôs only for this year ‚Äî  if the city‚Äôs lawmakers want to formalize the change, they will have to pass permanent legislation in the next year. Above, a participant celebrated an inaugural Indigenous Peoples‚Äô Day last year in Los Angeles, one of roughly 130 cities that have already renamed the federal holiday to focus on Native American history and culture. Seven states have passed similar legislation. (üì∏: Chelsea Guglielmino/Getty Images)

‚ÄúLive to 97 (years old) and you can do anything,‚Äù said John B. Goodenough, who just became the oldest person to win a Nobel Prize. The 97-year-old won the award in chemistry for his work alongside Stanley Whittingham and Akira Yoshino for their contributions to the development of lithium-ion batteries, which power everything from laptops to smartphones. (üì∏: Peter Summers/Getty Images)

A new law will make HIV-prevention drugs known as PrEP and PEP available without a prescription starting in January in California. The state will be the first in the country to allow pharmacists to provide the drugs without a prescription, nonprofit organization Equality California said. "The HIV epidemic is still a pressing issue today -- especially for LGBTQ people of color and folks in rural communities," the group's executive director, Rick Zbur, said. The legislation is a ‚Äúgiant step forward in getting to zero transmissions, zero deaths and zero stigma." (üì∏: Getty Images)

King Carl Gustaf of Sweden (front row, second from the right) has reduced the number of family members who will continue to receive taxpayer funds, stripping five of his grandchildren of their royal highness status, according to the Swedish Royal Court. The children will still be called prince/princess and duke/duchess, but won‚Äôt be expected to perform royal duties. Two grandchildren ‚Äî Princess Estele and Prince Oscar, who are second and third in line for the throne ‚Äî were excluded from the move. Several of the king‚Äôs children welcomed the change on Instagram ‚Äî his son, Prince Carl Philip, wrote that it would give his sons ‚Äúfreer choices in life.‚Äù (üì∏: Michael Campanella/Getty Images)

In the two centuries since its founding, Alabama‚Äôs capital of Montgomery, a majority-black city and the birthplace of the civil rights movement, has never had a black mayor. That changed Tuesday when Montgomery County probate judge Steven Reed won a runoff election, defeating television station owner David Woods by more than 16,000 votes. ‚ÄúIt was something that you never fathom but you hope for, you never expect to actually see it. And I did,‚Äù said one Montgomery resident. (üì∏: Steven Reed)

Look up for two meteor showers this week üí´The Draconid meteor shower will be active through October 10, and the South Taurid meteor shower is expected to peak on the evenings of October 9 and 10, according to the American Meteor Society. If this doesn't pan out, the Royal Astronomical Society of Canada's Observer's Handbook suggests that the peak could be on November 6. No special equipment is required, just lie back and look up ‚Äî ideally far away from artificial light that will obscure the view. Above, a meteor was captured streaking across the night sky in Myanmar during the 2018 Geminid meteor shower. (üì∏: YE AUNG THU/AFP/Getty Images)

üèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖüèÖ21. That‚Äôs how many world championship medals Simone Biles now has, making her the most decorated female gymnast in history. Biles broke the record after the USA women‚Äôs gymnastics team won the world championship in Stuttgart, Germany, on Tuesday. This win also marks Team USA‚Äôs fifth consecutive world team title. (üì∏: Laurence Griffiths/Getty Images)

Fourteen stitches and a black eye didn't stop former US President Jimmy Carter, who turned 95 last week, from his volunteer work. Just hours after being injured in a fall on Sunday, Carter traveled to Nashville with his wife, Rosalynn, to help build new porches for 21 homes as part of the 36th Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter Work Project with Habitat for Humanity. "I fell down and hit my forehead on a sharp edge and had to go to the hospital," said Carter, the oldest living US President. "But I had a No. 1 priority and that was to come to Nashville and build houses." (üì∏: Mark Humphery/AP)

Elizabeth Peratrovich, a civil rights activist and member of the Tlingit Nation, will become the first Alaskan Native to appear on US currency. Peratrovich was a key figure in the passing of the country‚Äôs first anti-discrimination law, the Anti-Discrimination Act of 1945, which prohibited discrimination based on race in Alaska. She also served as the Grand President of the Alaska Native Sisterhood. The coin‚Äôs design was unveiled during the Alaska Native Brothers and Alaska Native Sisters Convention at Alaska Pacific University on Saturday. The coins will be released in 2020, the 75th anniversary of the passing of the bill. (üì∏: United States Mint)

‚ÄúJeopardy!‚Äù host Alex Trebek has graced millions of living rooms for 35 years and more than 8,000 episodes, but Trebek recently hinted that his long tenure may be coming to an end. After months of battling pancreatic cancer, Trebek told CTV he has begun to get sores inside his mouth from the chemotherapy, which makes it difficult to enunciate. ‚ÄúThe thought of the pancreatic cancer does not frighten me,‚Äù he told CTV‚Äôs Lisa LaFlamme in an interview Friday. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm 79 years old. So, hey, I‚Äôve lived a good life, a full life, and I‚Äôm nearing the end of that life. I know that.‚Äù (üì∏: CTV News)

Astronauts Christina Koch and Jessica Meir are set to make history this month as they embark on the first all-female spacewalk üöÄ NASA had previously planned an all-female mission in March, but the plan was scuttled when officials realized there was only one medium-size spacesuit available at the International Space Station. When asked about spacesuit availability this time around, Koch said there are currently two medium spacesuits on board. (üì∏: @nasa)

Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è At least 217 Extinction Rebellion protesters were arrested in London at the start of a global two-week campaign called #InternationalRebellion to demand that governments take action on the climate crisis. Protesters shut down roads around the Parliament across large parts of Westminster on Monday in the UK capital. Protests are expected in at least 60 cities worldwide over the next two weeks. (üì∏: Guy Smallman/Getty Images, Anadolu Agency/Getty Images, Isabel Infantes/AFP/Getty Images)

US gymnastics star Simone Biles has two more amazing moves that will bear her name. While competing at the world championships in Stuttgart, Germany, she landed a triple-double (double backflip with three twist) during her floor exercise, and on the balance beam she nailed a double-double dismount (a double backflip with two twists). Biles, 22, already has two moves named for her ‚Äî one in the floor exercise and one on a vault. ‚ÄúMy goal going into tonight was to not be great,‚Äù Biles said, according to USA Gymnastics. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt to do great, it was to do well, and I feel like I accomplished that.‚Äù (üì∏ : Laurence Griffiths/Getty Images)

Fifteen years ago, Crystal Wang's father snapped a photo of her in the arms of a Harvard police officer during a campus visit. As it turned out, the photo was prophetic ‚Äî Wang is now a member of Harvard's Class of 2023. Naturally, she decided to recreate the moment with Officer Charles Marren. When the two reunited, Wang said the connection was genuine. Marren even gave her his personal cellphone number and told her to call if she ever needed anything. (üì∏:Crystal Wang, Stephanie Mitchell/Harvard Staff Photographer)

What do you do with $13,961 in dollar bills stapled to the walls of your restaurant? You donate it to hurricane relief. Armed with pliers and screwdrivers, staff and owners of Siesta Key Oyster Bar in Florida spent a month painstakingly removing the bills that guests stapled to the interior as part of a longstanding restaurant tradition. The owners said the money would be donated to the Bahamas Red Cross in Nassau. (üì∏: Siesta Key Oyster Bar)

A female-led team of architects oversaw the construction of Africa‚Äôs new tallest building, which soars 745 feet above Johannesburg and is expected to open later this year. Malika Walele, an architect on the 11-person team, told CNN about the difficulties she faced. "Specifically, being female, being young and being of color, there are a lot of challenges you face being in that building environment,‚Äù Walele said. "I really had to work hard to prove myself. I really had to step up and speak out ‚Äî make sure that I was being heard by the men." (üì∏:Legacy Group)

Philanthropist and global rights advocate Melinda Gates said she‚Äôs pledging $1 billion to expand women's power and influence. Over the next 10 years, Gates‚Äô company Pivotal Ventures will distribute money to partners that are working to advance gender equality. (üì∏: John Lamparski/Getty Images)

Got the munchies? Lowell Farms in Los Angeles just became the first fully legal cannabis restaurant in the US, according to the restaurant. The caf√©‚Äôs menu features seasonal, California-inspired dishes that are complementary to the effects of THC. Diners can also smoke joints, pipes and bongs, and consume edibles. (üì∏: Caf√© Lowell)

Prince Harry is suing the owners of UK tabloids the Sun and the Daily Mirror for allegedly hacking his phone. The court filings regard ‚Äúthe illegal interception of voicemail messages,‚Äù a Buckingham Palace spokesperson confirmed. A spokesperson for the Sun‚Äôs parent company told CNN the paper was aware of the claim but declined to comment further. A source at the Mirror‚Äôs parent company said that it was aware of the proceedings but had not yet received notification of them. The lawsuit comes just days after Harry‚Äôs wife Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, sued the UK‚Äôs Mail on Sunday, claiming the paper illegally published a private letter to her father. (üì∏: Chris Jackson/Getty Images)

The Freedom From Religion Foundation filed a complaint Thursday against Judge Tammy Kemp for giving a Bible to the defendant in a murder trial. The foundation said Kemp‚Äôs ‚Äúproselytizing actions overstepped judicial authority‚Äù and has asked the Texas State Commission on Judicial Conduct to investigate. The defendant, former Dallas police officer Amber Guyger, was sentenced to 10 years in prison for the murder of Botham Jean, whom she shot after entering his apartment thinking it was her own. At the end of the emotionally charged trial, Judge Kemp gave Guyger a hug and a Bible, and encouraged her to study it, saying: "This is your job for the next month... John 3:16. And this is where you start."

The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to take up an abortion case this term ‚Äî the first abortion case that will be argued since Trump-appointed Justices Brett Kavanaugh and Neil Gorsuch joined the bench, solidifying a conservative majority. The justices will consider a Louisiana law that requires doctors to obtain admitting privileges from a nearby hospital. Critics say the law is an attempt to unlawfully restrict abortion, and the district judge who struck it down in 2017 said it would leave the state with only one physician who would be able to perform the procedure.

‚ÄúDevolved Parliament,‚Äù a painting depicting the UK House of Commons filled with chimpanzees, shattered the auction record for a work by Bansky, the anonymous, mischievous street artist. The final sale price far exceeded auction house Sotheby's estimate of between $1.9 million and $2.5 million. The artist's previous auction record was about $1.8 million. (üì∏: Jonathan Brady/PA Images/Getty Images)

Americans will soon pay more for Scotch and Irish whiskies, Parmesan cheese, French wine and other products after the Trump administration said it would impose tariffs on $7.5 billion worth of European goods. The move, which will likely result in a retaliation from the EU, could trigger a damaging escalation in transatlantic trade tensions at a time when economies have been hurt by the fallout from the US-China trade war. (üì∏: Getty)

Instagram announced on Wednesday that it's rolling out a new anti-bullying feature called "Restrict," which it's been testing since July. Here's how it works: When you "Restrict" someone, their comments on your posts are only visible to them, and not others. Also, restricted users won't be able to see if you're active on Instagram at any given moment or if you've read their direct messages. Users can make a restricted person's comments show up for others by approving their comments. Instagram's reasoning for developing "Restrict" is that young Instagram users may be wary of blocking, unfollowing or reporting a bully because it could make the situation worse. Blocking or unfollowing the person could also make it harder to keep tabs on the bully's behavior. According to a 2018 study from Pew, 59% of US teens have been bullied or harassed online.
(üì∏: @instagram)

A portrait of 16-year-old Swedish climate activist @gretathunberg, by artists @mrdheo and @parizone, recently appeared on a building in Istanbul, Turkey, according to the artists. MrDheo posted about the mural, called ‚ÄúThe Time Is Now,‚Äù on Instagram. ‚ÄúWhat I love the most about Greta is not only her powerful message and awareness of what‚Äôs going on in the planet we all live in, but the fact that she‚Äôs telling it face to face to the biggest corrupt, greedy and selfish leaders of the world,‚Äù MrDheo wrote. (üì∏: Yasin AKGUL/AFP/Getty Images)

A Texas jury sentenced former police officer Amber Guyger to 10 years in prison for the murder of her neighbor, 26-year-old Botham Jean, in his Dallas apartment. Guyger had pleaded not guilty to the charge, arguing that she believed she was in her own apartment and firing at an intruder. The 31-year-old woman could have faced up to 99 years in prison for the conviction. (üì∏: Botham Jean/Facebook)

Sen. Bernie Sanders suspended his presidential campaign until further notice after doctors treated a blockage in an artery, senior adviser Jeff Weaver said Wednesday. ‚ÄúFollowing medical evaluation and testing he was found to have a blockage in one artery and two stents were successfully inserted,‚Äù Weaver said. The 78-year-old candidate began experiencing chest pain at a campaign event Tuesday night. After being treated, Weaver said, Sanders was speaking and in good spirits.

Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, is suing UK tabloid the Mail on Sunday, alleging that it illegally published a private letter she sent to her estranged father. Her husband, Prince Harry, issued a strongly worded statement accusing the British paper of selectively editing the letter ‚Äî a claim that the tabloid denies. He also alleged that British tabloids are waging a campaign against Meghan that mirrors how his mother, Princess Diana, was treated. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen what happens when someone I love is commoditised to the point that they are no longer treated or seen as a real person. I lost my mother and now I watch my wife falling victim to the same powerful forces,‚Äù he wrote. (üì∏: Chris Jackson/Getty Images)

One day after violent protests erupted across Hong Kong, protesters gathered and spelled out, "Hong Kongers add oil, free Hong Kong" using origami figures. The phrase "add oil" is used to express support and encouragement. On Tuesday, police said an officer shot and injured an 18-year-old man, marking a major escalation in violence that could galvanize the protests further. Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è They're in our oceans, soil, air, snow -- and even in your cup of tea. ‚òïÔ∏è Plastic tea bags are shedding billions of shards of microplastics into their water, according to a new study. Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è More than 100 scientists from 36 countries worked on a new landmark report from the United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), and they say there may be some impacts to the global climate ‚Äî like some amount of sea level rise ‚Äî that can no longer be stopped. And even though there is uncertainty in the report about what exactly the future holds, the authors are unambiguous on this: Despite the damage that has been done, humanity still has a choice.

For instance, rates of sea level rise are projected to reach 15 millimeters per year by 2100 under a high emissions scenario. But if humans draw down global greenhouse gases very soon, sea levels are expected to rise much slower at 4 millimeters per year. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #climateweek #climatecrisis

The UK's Supreme Court has ruled that Boris Johnson suspended Parliament unlawfully, dealing a stunning and historic blow to the Prime Minister. Forget Atlantis. Researchers recently discovered a lost continent called Greater Adria, which was roughly the size of Greenland and buried under Southern Europe about 140 million years ago. Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è Swedish climate activist @gretathunberg and 15 other young people filed a complaint with the United Nations on Monday alleging that five countries ‚Äî Germany, France, Brazil, Argentina and Turkey ‚Äî have violated human rights by not taking adequate action to stop the climate crisis. The complaint was filed after Thunberg delivered an impassioned speech to world leaders at the UN Climate Summit, saying: ‚ÄúYou have stolen my dreams and my childhood with your empty words.‚Äù #climateweek #climatecrisis #unga (üì∏:Sarah Silbiger/Getty Images)

A pair of ancient skeletons, known as the ‚ÄúLovers of Modena‚Äù because they were buried holding hands, were both men, scientists say. Scientists announced Wednesday that they successfully created two embryos from the northern white rhino ‚Äî a crucial turning point in the race to save the majestic animal from extinction. The last two northern white rhinos left worldwide ‚Äî Fatu and Najin ‚Äî are both female and living at the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya. The last male, Sudan, died last year, raising fears the subspecies is on the verge of extinction. (üì∏: Tony Karumba/AFP/Getty Images)

This is Saturn's new portrait. The Hubble Space Telescope captured the view on June 20, when Saturn was about 845 million miles from Earth and tilted towards us. Even the more faint inner rings are visible here. The planet's vivid amber color is due to a smog-like haze occurring during its summer where solar ultraviolet radiation creates reactions in the atmosphere. Just like Earth, Saturn goes through seasons but they last longer like in "Game of Thrones." Saturn's seasons can last more than seven years.
(üì∏: @NASA/A. Simon/M.H. Wong/ESA)

Trump administration officials announced Wednesday that newly proposed enforcement policy would require flavored e-cigarette companies to take their products off the market. A new law mandates public schools across New York to allow a brief moment of silence each year to mark the anniversary of the September 11 terrorist attacks. Gov. Andrew Cuomo's office said it's intended to "encourage dialogue and education in the classroom." President Trump abruptly announced Tuesday that he had asked his national security adviser, John Bolton, to resign, saying he "strongly disagreed" with many of Bolton's suggestions "as did others in the administration." This new Dia de los Muertos Barbie, or Day of the Dead Barbie, will be released on Thursday and celebrates the annual Mexican festival when people honor their departed loved ones. The collectible doll has flowers on her dress, a crown of monarch butterflies and marigolds, and a skull painted on her face ‚Äî a popular practice during the festival. Monarch butterflies typically migrate in Mexico for the winter and arrive around the same time as the festival, and they have come to symbolize the souls of loved ones coming back to visit. This year, Dia de los Muertos will take place on November 1 and 2.
(üì∏: @mattel)

Extreme changes in the atmosphere killed almost 100% of life on Earth about 2 billion years ago in what scientists are calling the ‚ÄúGreat Oxidation Event,‚Äù according to a new study üåé Billions of years ago, only micro-organisms lived on Earth, and they created an excess in oxygen which they couldn‚Äôt sustain. Once they exhausted the nutrients required to create oxygen, the Earth‚Äôs atmosphere was knocked off-kilter. That led to an enormous drop in the amount of life on Earth. (üì∏: Malcolm Hodgskiss)

More than 150,000 people will have their marijuana convictions effectively erased from their record under a New York State law that went into effect Wednesday. The law also removes criminal penalties for possession of less than 2 ounces of marijuana and reduces the penalty for possession of less than 1 ounce to a $50 fine. (üì∏: AFP/Getty Images)

US health officials announced Friday that they are now aware of at least 450 possible cases of severe lung disease that could be caused by vaping, and three confirmed deaths. These cases, which have occurred in 33 states and one jurisdiction, include some cases that are still under investigation by state health officials. An official from the Centers for Disease Control warned users Friday not to buy e-cigarette products off the street or modify them in any way. She added the primary way to prevent these illness is to not vape at all. (üì∏: Getty Images)

Jermaine Bell had been saving money in his piggy bank so he and his family could spend it on a trip to Disney World for his 7th birthday. Instead, the 6-year-old bought used those funds to buy hundreds of hotdogs for people displaced by #HurricaneDorian in his hometown of Allendale, South Carolina. Hampton University said it is partnering with the University of the Bahamas to allow students who have been displaced by Hurricane Dorian to spend the fall semester on its Virginia campus tuition-free. The students who transfer will receive free room and board for one semester, with the option of staying on after at the standard tuition rate. Hurricane Dorian slammed the Bahamas as a Category 5 storm‚Äîthe strongest ever to hit the islands‚Äîwiping out entire neighborhoods and leaving at least 20 dead. (üì∏: Rob Ostermaier/The Daily Press/AP)

Robert Mugabe, who ruled Zimbabwe with an iron fist for more than three decades, has died at the age of 95. Mugabe -- who infamously claimed that "only God" could ever remove him from office -- was deposed in a coup in 2017, when members of his own party turned against him after he dismissed then vice-president Emmerson Mnangagwa to make way for his wife, Grace. Mnangagwa would go on to become Zimbabwe's next president. "It is with the utmost sadness that I announce the passing on of Zimbabwe's founding father and former President, Cde Robert Mugabe," tweeted Mnangagwa on Friday. Once touted internationally as the hope of his nation, Mugabe left office with a grim legacy, after waging a campaign of oppression and violence to maintain power, and driving into poverty a country once known as the breadbasket of southern Africa. "This is a man who had so much to offer to Zimbabweans, but he didn't, he focused on himself," said Trevor Ncube, one of the Zimbabwe's most powerful publishers. (üì∏: Jekesai Njikizana/AFP/Getty Images)

The sky turned purple over parts of Florida on Wednesday, causing a bit of a stir among those who were watching for #HurricaneDorian. Residents flooded social media with pictures of the phenomenon, which scientists call a "scattering" ‚Äî the low-level clouds from Dorian scattered light in such a long wavelength that the sky appeared purple üíú ‚ÄúThe sky was definitely a pleasant reminder that we must have hope and if we only believe in the sun when it‚Äôs shining we will never get through the night,‚Äù said one onlooker. (üì∏: Amy Pope-Latham, Berivan Keskin)

‚ÄúThere is nothing left,‚Äù said CNN‚Äôs Paul Newton of Man-O-War, an island in the Bahamas that was ravaged by #HurricaneDorian this week. The storm slammed into the Bahamas as a Category 5 hurricane with 180 mph winds, leaving at least 20 dead, though the prime minster expected the death toll to rise. Hurricane Dorian was downgraded to a Category 2 storm on Thursday morning, but was expected to remain powerful as it approached the Carolinas. Click the link in our bio for live updates on the storm. Kimberly Teehee was named the Cherokee Nation's first official representative to Congress on Thursday, fulfilling a promise made to the tribe in a nearly 200-year-old treaty with the federal government. The treaty doesn't specify whether Teehee would be a voting member of the legislature, and her appointment requires congressional approval. "This journey is just beginning and we have a long way to go to see this through to fruition," says Teehee, a former senior policy adviser for Native American Affairs during President Barack Obama's administration and currently executive director of government affairs for the Cherokee Nation. Her historic nomination stems from the 1835 Treaty of New Echota in which the Cherokee were forced to leave the Southeast for present-day Oklahoma, a devastating journey known today as the Trail of Tears. (üì∏: AP Photo/Sue Ogrocki)

A Catholic school in Nashville is facing a backlash over a decision to remove the "Harry Potter" book series from its shelves üìö‚ú® On August 28, Rev. Dan Reehil, the pastor of St. Edward Catholic School, sent an e-mail to school staff explaining his reasoning for removing the books from the school's library. "The curses and spells used in the books are actual curses and spells; which when read by a human being risk conjuring evil spirits into the presence of the person reading the texts." Representatives from the school couldn't be reached to comment Tuesday. (üì∏: Peter Macdiarmid/Getty Images)

Chella Phillips hunkered down in her home with 97 homeless dogs üêï as Hurricane Dorian pummeled the Bahamas for days, leaving behind catastrophic damage. Phillips said 79 dogs shared her master bedroom, and not one of the very good boys and girls attempted to jump onto her bed. ‚ÄúEach island has [an] abundance of homeless dogs, my heart is so broken for the ones without a place to hide a Cat 5 monster and only God can protect them now,‚Äù Phillips said on Facebook. On Monday, she said her home in the Bahamas capital, Nassau, flooded but that all 97 pups were doing well. üê∂
(üì∏: Chella Phillips/Facebook)

NASA astronaut Christina Koch took photos of Hurricane Dorian on Monday from the International Space Station. The slow-moving Category 3 storm continues to lash the Bahamas with fierce winds. As it lingers over the islands, the storm is carving a path of devastation: knocking homes to the ground and claiming the lives of at least five people, among them an 8-year-old boy. Dorian is expected to move "dangerously" close to Florida's east coast later today. It no longer poses a threat to Florida in terms of landfall, but coastal residents will still feel the impacts, CNN Meteorologist Robert Shackelford said. (üì∏: Christian Koch/NASA)

A 17-month-old girl was one of the 22 people injured in a shooting spree in West Texas. Anderson Davis will have surgery Monday for her injuries, which include shrapnel in her chest, a hole through her bottom lip and tongue, and damage to her front teeth, her mother, Kelby Davis, told CNN on Sunday. Despite her injuries, Anderson is expected to make a full recovery, her parents said.
Seven people were killed after a gunman went on a shooting spree Saturday that began during a traffic stop in Midland and continued as he drove into Odessa 20 miles away. The police confronted him in a movie theater parking lot and killed him in a shootout, Odessa police said. "We hurt so badly for the families whose loved ones didn't survive this tragedy," Kelby and Garret Davis said in a statement emailed to CNN later Sunday. "We are thankful for our beautiful baby girl and look forward to reuniting her at home with her twin brother soon." (üì∏: Kelby Davis)

Homeowners are increasingly looking for ways to bring the outdoors inside their homes. For some homeowners in Long Island‚Äôs North Fork, this means porches, balconies, and lots of windows. ‚ÄúMy clients are coming out of Manhattan and Brooklyn and they are looking for that combination of indoor and outdoor living,‚Äù said one real estate agent in Southold, New York. One Long Island home was built to incorporate a surrounding meadow. ‚ÄúWe wanted to respect the idea that a meadow was here,‚Äù said the architect. ‚ÄúRather than obliterating the meadow and planting a large trophy home, we wanted to take the idea of peeling the meadow up and kind of tuck the house underneath it.‚Äù (üì∏: Ty Cole, Michael Moran)

A remarkably complete skull belonging to an early human ancestor has been discovered in Ethiopia. The skull represents the ancestor known as Australopithecus anamensis, that lived between 3.9 and 4.2 million years ago. "A. anamensis was already a species that we knew quite a bit about, but this is the first cranium of the species ever discovered," said Stephanie Melillo, a researcher at the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. "It is good to finally be able to put a face to the name." (üì∏: Cleveland Museum of Natural History)

At least five people were killed and 21 others injured Saturday when a gunman in West Texas drove around shooting from his vehicle, authorities said. The shooter was later killed by law enforcement officers.

Mattel this week unveiled two new Barbies modeled after civil rights icon Rosa Parks and Sally Ride, the first American woman in space. "Both Sally Ride and Rosa Parks made the world better for future generations of girls," a Mattel spokesperson said. The dolls are part of the company‚Äôs collection of historical figure Barbies, which also includes Frida Kahlo, Amelia Earhart and Katherine Johnson. (üì∏: Mattel)

This Charlottesville, Virginia, intersection was the scene of a hate crime in 2017. Now, it‚Äôs a symbol of unity. Artist and Charlottesville native Jake Van Yahres on Friday grabbed some white chalk and transformed the spot where two years ago a man drove his car into a crowd of counter-protesters at a white nationalist rally, killing 32-year-old Heather Heyer. Van Yahres said he came up with the idea of interlaced fingers to symbolize people of different races coming together. ‚ÄúI've been looking at that crosswalk for about a year trying to figure out what I could do with it as an artist," he said. "Like what if we could turn the message around in some way?" (üì∏: Jake Van Yahres)

Daisy-May Demetre, a 9-year-old model who has two prosthetic legs, is set to walk the runway at New York Fashion Week for Lulu et Gigi Couture. Daisy-May was born with fibular hemimelia, a condition in which part or all of the fibular bone is missing, and underwent a double amputation when she was 18 months old. Her dad says she‚Äôs been modeling for the past year and a half. "She inspired me by showing me who she was. She takes on life with a smile on her face and she does remarkable things," he told CNN. "Whether it's dancing, singing, she is a very special little girl." (üì∏: Emma Wright/Lulu et Gigi)

17-year-old David Ledbetter spent last Saturday walking up to people waiting in line at Popeyes and handing out sample ballots and voter registration forms üó≥Ô∏è "We were seeing how long the lines were [at Popeyes] and figured we would try to go get individuals to vote," the high school senior told CNN. "I was just hoping that the individuals would register to vote." The group he was with ran out of forms after speaking with dozens and dozens of people in Charlotte, North Carolina. Ledbetter is only 17, but he's already pre-registered to vote for when he turns 18.(üì∏:David Ledbetter)

Young activists, including Greta Thunberg from Sweden, rallied in front of the United Nations in New York on Friday calling for action to protect the environment. Thunberg, who traveled to New York on a zero-emissions sailboat to speak at the UN Climate Action Summit on September 23, has become the figurehead of a burgeoning movement of youth climate activists after her weekly school-strike movement, "Fridays for the future," spread to more than 100 cities worldwide.‚Å£‚Å£

The first all-female crew to conduct a hurricane reconnaissance mission for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration took off Thursday. Capt. Kristie Twining, Cmdr. Rebecca Waddington and Lt. Lindsey Norman were tasked with learning about Hurricane Dorian, and the mission lasted more than seven hours on Thursday, according to Flightaware.com. Hurricane Dorian is forecast to hit the US mainland Monday evening into Tuesday morning as a Category 4 hurricane, which means it could be the strongest hurricane to strike Florida's east coast since Hurricane Andrew in 1992, according to CNN meteorologist Brandon Miller.
