(üì∏: Rebecca Pavlak-Thiel)

Let there be light! ‚òÄÔ∏èThe longest day of the year has arrived in the northern hemisphere. Thousands of people gather at Stonehenge in England every year to celebrate summer solstice. The 4,500-year-old Neolithic monument, which is still surrounded in mystery, is characterized by a ring of stones, some nine meters high, and offers insight into the dawn of astronomy. In the early hours of the morning on June 21st, the sun rises above Stonehenge's Heel Stone, which stands on the avenue leading up to the monument's Stone Circle. The morning rays shine directly into the center of the site. On the winter solstice, on December 22, the effect is reversed, with the view from the avenue being of the sunrise shining through the stones on the opposite side. #stonehenge #summersolstice (üì∏: Finnbarr Webster/Getty Images)

State Sen. Luis Sepulveda celebrates the passing of his bill that will allow undocumented immigrants to obtain driver's licenses in New York. "We are taking a stand for the rights of immigrants in a time where their livelihoods are being threatened and degraded to extreme degrees," said Sepulveda, the bill's original sponsor. Twelve other states have similar provisions, state Sen. Gustavo Rivera said.
(üì∏: Hans Pennink/AP)

Five female anchors at NY1, a local TV station in New York, filed a lawsuit on Wednesday against the news organization, alleging systematic age and gender discrimination. The suit claims management strongly favored younger female and male anchors. "Sadly, after dedicating over 100 years of award-winning journalism to NY1, our five clients have clearly been told that their careers are over, as NY1 seems to believe that younger faces, when it comes to women, are a 'better look' for the bottom line," said Douglas Wigdor, an attorney who represents the women.

Maureen Huff, a spokesperson for Charter, which owns NY1, said the company takes the allegations seriously and that it has "not found any merit to them" as it works to complete a "thorough review."

In Chennai, India's sixth largest city, millions of people are running out of water as nearby reservoirs are nearly all dry. This image shows the dried-out Puzhal reservoir compared to last year. Every day, hundreds of thousands of residents have no choice but to stand in line for hours in soaring summer temperatures, filling dozens of cans and plastic containers. Droughts in India are an annual problem, but this year's water shortage has coincided with a fatal nationwide heatwave. As cities struggle to provide enough resources, those on the front lines of the crisis say it's only going to get worse.
(üì∏: @MaxarTechnologies)

You might be forgiven for thinking you were looking at some obscure underwater phenomenon here, where houses and trees appear submerged under giant oceanic waves. But what you're actually looking at are the skies over Virginia. A rare formation of wave-shaped clouds was spotted at Virginia's Smith Mountain Lake on Tuesday. These clouds form on windy and unstable days, but when conditions are just right, the natural phenomenon, known as Kelvin-Helmholtz Waves, occurs. The National Weather Service defines it as "vertical waves in the air associated with wind shear across statically-stable regions." In other words, different layers of the atmosphere have differing wind speeds, creating the appearance of rolling waves.(üì∏: Amy Christie Hunter)

Pennsylvania is the latest state to officially recognize #Juneteenth, which is celebrated on June 19 and commemorates the end of slavery in the United States. That leaves just four states that don't recognize the holiday: Hawaii, North Dakota, South Dakota and Montana. In 1980, Texas was the first state to make Juneteenth, also called Emancipation Day, a state holiday, although it had been celebrated informally since 1865. Above, people in Philadelphia celebrate Juneteenth in 2018. (üì∏: Yong Kim/The Philadelphia Inquirer via AP)

NASA spotted a new impact crater on the surface of Mars, and the image shows some blue and purple on what is often referred to as the ‚Äúred planet.‚Äù Veronica Bray, HiRISE team member and University of Arizona scientist, said the blue area could potentially indicate "water ice." The crater is about 50 feet wide and is estimated to have formed between September 2016 and February 2019.
(üì∏: @NASA)

Who is the most prolific scorer in world football's biggest competition? If you said Cristiano Ronaldo, you would be wrong. If you said Lionel Messi, you would also be wrong. That title belongs to Brazilian great, Marta, who has now scored more goals at the World Cup than any man or woman. She netted a penalty yesterday, securing a 1-0 over Italy and her 17th Women's World Cup goal, taking over Germany's Miroslav Klose as the outright leading scorer in World Cup history. Marta, a six-time FIFA Player of the Year and widely regarded as the greatest woman to ever play the game, celebrated her feat by kissing her boot. (üì∏: Robert Cianflone/Getty Images via @cnnsport)

This month, Selah Schneiter, a 10-year-old from Colorado, successfully scaled the 3,000-foot ‚ÄúNose‚Äù route of El Capitan in Yosemite National Park. With help from her dad, Schneiter took five days to complete the notoriously difficult climb. ‚ÄúOur big motto was, ‚ÄòHow do you eat an elephant?‚Äô Small bites. One pitch at a time, one move at a time, one day at a time,‚Äù Selah told CNN affiliate KFSN. (üì∏: Schneiter family)

It was a giant leap for womankind. On June 18, 1983, at age 32, Sally Ride launched into the atmosphere aboard the Space Shuttle Challenger, becoming the first American woman, and the youngest American, to go into space. When she joined the space program in the 1970s, NASA was still overwhelmingly male, so adjustments had to be made before her first flight. In one often reported anecdote, the male engineers tasked with planning a "makeup kit" asked Ride how many tampons she might need for a weeklong journey. ‚ÄúIs 100 the right number?‚Äù Ride replied: ‚ÄúNo. That would not be the right number.‚Äù Ride, who died in 2012, was posthumously awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President Barack Obama in 2013. (üì∏: @NASA)

Former Vice President Joe Biden on Tuesday stopped by the Stonewall Inn, an LGBTQ landmark in New York. The bar is celebrating #PrideMonth and marking the 50th anniversary of the 1969 Stonewall uprising, a series of violent confrontations between the bar's patrons the city's police that became a turning point in the modern LGBTQ rights movement. Biden, who is running for president, bought a round of drinks for everyone at the bar, according to Will Garden, who captured this photo and videos. (üì∏: @alsoknownasbaby)

This is Mangal. Until the age of two, Mangal was Madina, one of seven daughters chosen by her parents to live as a boy under an Afghan tradition called "bacha posh," a Dari term that translates to "dressed as a boy." In Afghanistan's deeply patriarchal society, sons are highly valued over daughters -- to the point where a family is deemed "incomplete" without a boy, says Nadia Hashimi, author of the best-selling 2014 bacha posh novel "The Pearl That Broke Its Shell." The transition is temporary, and bacha posh children are expected to shed their male identities once they hit puberty and return to living as girls -- something that doesn't always come easily. "I made my daughter like a boy to serve me food and water when I am working in the desert," Mangal's father told CNN. The centuries-old tradition says much about the discrimination faced by Afghan girls quite literally from the moment they're born. #AsEquals

Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è This incredible photo shows a team of sled dogs wading through flood water on what is normally frozen sea ice. It shows the reality of Greenland's melting ice sheet -- the second largest on the planet -- in what's been predicted will be a record year for ice loss. The picture was taken by Steffen Olsen, a scientist with the Danish Meteorological Institute, during a routine mission in northwest Greenland to retrieve weather monitoring tools placed by his colleagues on the sea ice. But, because of the flood water, he couldn't find them. Thomas Mote, a research scientist at the University of Georgia who studies Greenland's climate, told CNN last week that while previous melt periods occurred in 2007, 2010 and 2012, "we didn't see anything like this prior to the late 1990s." Worsening heavy melts like this could have a major effect on rising sea levels, one of the most dangerous effects of climate change, that could drive millions of people living in coastal communities from their homes. Photo: Steffen M. Olsen / AP

The residents of Sommar√∏y, meaning ‚Äúsummer island," off the northwest coast of Norway have a slightly unconventional relationship with time. After a long, dark winter, the island is treated to 69 straight days of uninterrupted daylight from mid-May to late July. ‚ÄúIn the middle of the night, which city folk might call ‚Äò2 a.m.,‚Äô you can spot children playing soccer, people painting their houses or mowing their lawns, and teens going for a swim,‚Äù said Kjell Ove Hveding. Islanders are hoping that by formally recognizing their home as a ‚Äútime-free‚Äù zone they can be free of traditional opening hours and to introduce flexibility in school and working hours. (üì∏: Courtesy Visit Norway)

This Monterey Cypress tree üå≥ in La Jolla, California, which Theodor Seuss Geisel, aka Dr. Seuss, could see from his mountaintop home, has fallen. The tree was estimated to be about 80 to 100 years old, and was thought to have inspired the author to write the 1971 children‚Äôs book ‚ÄúThe Lorax.‚Äù The city plans to plant a replacement in the area, according to a spokesman for the San Diego Parks and Recreation Department. (üì∏: SherryVSmith_Images/iStockphoto/Getty Images)

A Confederate statue in Nashville's Centennial Park was vandalized late Sunday night with red paint spelling out the words "They were racists" over the names of more than 500 soldiers who fought in the Civil War, according to CNN affiliate WZTV. Police were reviewing security footage in the search for suspects. (üì∏: Mark Humphrey/AP)

Last week, Greenland lost an estimated 2 billion tons of ice in a single day‚Äîan unusually large melt for the middle of June, researchers said. Greenland's "melting season" began a month earlier than usual this year, and ‚Äúall signs seem to be pointing to a large melt season,‚Äù said James Mote, a research scientist. While such a sudden spike in melting is not unprecedented, he said, "we've seen a sequence of these large melt seasons, starting in 2007, that would have been unprecedented earlier in the record." For more, follow @cnnclimate. (üì∏: Brice Laine/CNN)

Drone footage shows the massive scale of Sunday‚Äôs protests in Hong Kong, where organizers said nearly 2 million people took to the streets to march against a controversial extradition bill. As the black-clad demonstrators marched, many demanded that the city‚Äôs leader, Carrie Lam, step down. Lam on Saturday suspended the bill, which would allow suspects in the semi-autonomous city to be extradited to mainland China, but stopped short of scrapping it permanently.

"This is the power of persistence, the reward of me never giving up," says Xia Boyu, a 69-year-old double amputee who reached the top of Mount Everest last month, more than 40 years after his first attempt. Xia‚Äôs first Everest attempt in 1975 left him badly frostbitten, eventually leading to both of his legs being amputated. Undeterred, Xia went back again in 2014, 2015 and 2016 ‚Äî and each time he was thwarted by weather. He finally reached the summit on May 14, making him the first double amputee to reach the top of Everest from the Nepal side. (üì∏: Prakash Mathema/AFP/Getty Images)

Britain‚Äôs Prince Harry and Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, have released a new image of their son, Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor, in honor of Father's Day. Pampers is partnering with changing table company Koala Kare to bring 5,000 diaper-changing stations to men‚Äôs restrooms across the US and Canada, saying it‚Äôs time for public restrooms to catch up with the responsibilities of modern fathers. The installation of the first 500 new changing tables will begin in the next few weeks. (üì∏: Shutterstock)

This Cincinnati skyscraper is in full spirit for #Pride üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåàwith a mural created from 26,000 Post-Its. Since Colorado legalized marijuana in 2014, ‚Äúthe combined marijuana tax, license and fee revenue had reached $1.02 billion, and marijuana sales alone have exceeded $6.56 billion,‚Äù officials said. The pot industry employs about 40,000 people statewide, and the tax revenue has funded public education programs, as well as health care and mental health services. "This industry is helping grow our economy by creating jobs and generating valuable revenue that is going towards preventing youth consumption, protecting public health and safety and investing in public school construction," Gov. Jared Polis said. (üì∏: Getty Images)

Everybody hurts sometimes‚Äîeven fish. In a study looking at a tiny, monogamous fish üêü called convict cichlids, researchers discovered that females separated from a preferred partner showed a "pessimistic bias" ‚Äî in other words, a bleaker outlook on life ‚Äî when presented with a challenge üíî "Many psychologists decided that only humans can feel some emotion to their partner, but with this study, we have shown that is not correct," says Fran√ßois-Xavier Dechaume-Moncharmont, one of the authors of the study. (üì∏: Getty Images)

Celebrities and others on social media are posting blue squares with the hashtag #blueforsudan to raise awareness of the deadly uprising in Sudan, where protesters are seeking a full transition to civilian-led democracy. This comes after peaceful protests led the country‚Äôs longtime dictator to step down in April. Since then, the North African country has been ruled by military forces that are reluctant to relinquish full control. As civilian and military leaders have negotiated, protesters have continued to take to the streets in a mass civil disobedience campaign. Earlier this month, military forces opened fire on a pro-democracy sit-in in the capital, Khartoum, leaving at least 118 dead, according to doctors. The blue social media posts were inspired by the favorite color of Mohamed Hashim Mattar, 26, who was allegedly shot and killed by Sudanese forces.

Ella Casano, now 12, had to have IV infusions every six to eight weeks when she was younger. The process scared her, so she came up with a creative solution to disguise the medicine ‚Äî a teddy bear. Seeing how delighted the nurses were with the idea, Ella and her mother started the process to patent, manufacture and distribute the invention they named Medi Teddy. They launched a GoFundMe to raise money for their first order, and once the bears are made, they plan on giving them to children at no cost.
(üì∏: Medi Teddy)

The street in front of NASA headquarters has been renamed Hidden Figures Way to honor the work of Katherine Johnson, Dorothy Vaughan, and Mary Jackson ‚Äî the so-called "human computers" who did the complex calculations that made space travel possible üöÄ The world didn't fully learn of their incredible story until 2016, when the best-selling book and popular movie "Hidden Figures" were released. "I just want to say these were the three hidden figures in a very prominent book that became a magnificent movie that started a movement that brought all of us here today," NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine said in a ceremony to unveil the new street sign. "Here we are, 50 years after the landing of the Apollo 11 Moon lander, celebrating those figures who were, at the time, not celebrated."
(üì∏: @NASA)

In an effort to cut harmful waste damaging the Canada‚Äôs ecosystems, the country will ban many single-use plastic items, including bags, straws, cutlery and stirring sticks, by 2021. "Plastic waste ends up in our landfills and incinerators, litters our parks and beaches, and pollutes our rivers, lakes, and oceans, entangling and killing turtles, fish, and marine mammals,‚Äù Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said Monday. The Canadian leader said that plastic has become ‚Äúa problem we simply can‚Äôt ignore." For more, follow @cnnclimate. (üì∏: Getty Images)

Ecuador just became one of only a few South American countries to legalize same-sex marriage, in a major victory for LGBTQ rights in the Catholic-majority nation. "The judges decided to be on the right side of history," said advocate Pamela Troy. Since 2015, Ecuador has legally recognized same-sex unions, where couples are granted the same rights as married couples, with the exception of adoption. The other countries in South America that have legalized same-sex marriage include Argentina, Brazil, Colombia and Uruguay, according to the International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans and Intersex Association.
(üì∏: Rodrigo Buendia/AFP/Getty Images)

A House panel unanimously voted to advance a bill to reauthorize the September 11th Victims Compensation Fund on Wednesday, a day after comedian Jon Stewart made an impassioned speech in which he scolded members of Congress. "Shameful," he said of the lawmakers who didn't attend the hearing. "It's an embarrassment to the country and it is a stain on this institution." The bill, which now will head to the House floor for the full chamber to vote, would extend funding for Sept. 11 first responders through 2090. (üì∏: Zach Gibson/Getty Images)

The steps of a New York City park will be transformed from gray granite to the city‚Äôs largest #Pride flag üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà this weekend. The flag, which is located on the southern tip of Roosevelt Island, is made of vinyl, measures 12-by-100 feet, and will be the largest LGBTQ pride flag in the city, according to organizers. (üì∏: @4freedomspark)

Police officers took a break after four consecutive days of trying to contain massive protests in Hong Kong. On Wednesday, tens of thousands of people surrounded government buildings and forced officials to postpone debate over a controversial bill that would allow extraditions to mainland China. Critics say the measure would leave anyone on Hong Kong soil vulnerable to persecution by Chinese authorities and undermine the semi-autonomous city's independent legal system. Swipe through ‚û°Ô∏è to see more from the protests. Check out our Instagram story to learn more ‚¨ÜÔ∏è (üì∏: CNN)

Protesting a wave of highly restrictive abortion laws in several states, @arianagrande decided to donate the proceeds from her recent concert in Atlanta to Planned Parenthood. The donation totaled around $250,000, according to People magazine. Leana Wen, the president of women's health care provider, praised the pop star's generosity, saying it comes at a critical time. "In Georgia and across the country, anti-women's health politicians are trying to ban all safe, legal abortion." Georgia's law, set to go into effect Jan. 1, would ban abortions after a fetal heartbeat can be detected, which can be as early as six weeks into pregnancy. (üì∏: Kevin Mazur/Getty Images)

The US Women's National Team clinched 13-0 victory against Thailand‚Äîthe heaviest defeat in #worldcup history‚Äîon Tuesday, but the team quickly faced criticism from some who said celebrating each goal smacked of poor sportsmanship. Players and coaches have defended their strategy and their cheers, noting that goal differential can be a deciding factor in the World Cup. "We knew that every goal could matter in this group stage game and when it comes to celebrations this was a really good team performance and I think it was important for us to celebrate together," said striker @alexmorgan13. Coach Jill Ellis agreed, saying, "As a coach, I don't find it my job to harness my players and rein them in because this is what they've dreamed about. This is it for them, this is a world championship."
(üì∏: Robert Cianflone/Getty Images)

Tens of thousands of demonstrators are blocking roads in Hong Kong, protesting against a controversial bill that would allow China to extradite fugitives from the city. Protesters began arriving outside the Legislative Council buildings on Tuesday night, where they were greeted by a heavy police presence and bag searches. By Wednesday morning, tens of thousands of mainly young people had arrived in the area, bringing central Hong Kong to a standstill. Police fired a water canon on a protester and used pepper spray on others, while some protesters were seen wearing helmets and goggles, and pulling bricks from the sidewalks. Although Hong Kong is part of China, it was a British colony until 1997, and has separate laws and no capital punishment, unlike mainland China. Many people fear that the proposed extradition law means they could be taken from Hong Kong by Chinese authorities for political reasons. Hundreds of businesses, parents and teachers have called for a boycott of work and school on Wednesday to show their opposition to the bill. The debate that lawmakers were due to have over the bill on Wednesday has been postponed to a later date. üì∏: Ben Westcott/CNN & Anthony Wallace/Getty Images

‚ÄúBehind me, a filled room of 9/11 first responders and in front of me, a nearly empty Congress.‚Äù Comedian Jon Stewart, a longtime advocate for 9/11 first responders, scolded lawmakers in a powerful speech before Congress on Tuesday. Stewart was in Washington to fight for the reauthorization of the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund, which is meant to cover health care costs for those who were injured in the terrorist attacks or in cleanup efforts that followed. ‚ÄúThey did their jobs with courage, grace, tenacity, humility. Eighteen years later, do yours,‚Äù Stewart said.

Canada's government is expected to approve a bill banning the captivity of whales, dolphins and porpoises üê¨üê≥üêã and punish violators with fines of up to $150,000. Supporters of the measure, known colloquially as the "Free Willy" bill after the 1993 movie, celebrated its passage in the House of Commons on Monday, using the hashtag #emptythetanks on social media.
(üì∏: Center for Whale Research)

Botswana's High Court has overturned a colonial-era law criminalizing consensual same-sex relations in a landmark victory for Africa's LGBTQ movements. "A democratic society is one that embraces tolerance, diversity and open-mindedness," Justice Michael Leburu said. Tuesdays' historic ruling is win for LGBTQ activists and supporters in a country and region where homosexuality remains largely taboo. Out of 54 African countries, at least 31 of them have enacted laws making it illegal to have gay sex, according to the International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans and Intersex Association (ILGA).
(üì∏: Keikantse Phele/Twitter and AFPTV)

This bright blue wooden house, known as the Crawley Edge Boat Shed, is the most photographed building in Perth, Australia. Crowds of Instagrammers flock to the Swan River to get a shot of it -- but although it looks serene, this tourist attraction is highly problematic for locals. Perth city council is concerned about overtourism in the area, and a nearby restaurant has had issues with crowds of visitors using their facilities. In response, the city is spending AUS $400,000 ($278,000 US) on installing a solar-powered public toilet nearby to accommodate visitors. üì∏ s_porter01/Getty Images (via @cnntravel)

Using duct tape and mailbox letters, Cody Barlow decorated the tailgate of his truck with this message: "Not all country boys are bigots. Happy Pride Month." He shared this picture on Facebook on Thursday, hoping to encourage compassion. He did not expect it to be shared more than 70,000 times in four days, filling his inbox with messages of gratitude from around the world. "I live in a rural area in Oklahoma, surrounded by small towns in every direction, and I'm sure this is not a very welcome message around here," he wrote on Facebook. Barlow says the positive reactions far outweigh the negative ones and that he's working on making appearances with his truck at Pride parades throughout the state for the rest of #PrideMonth üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà
(üì∏:Cody Barlow/Facebook)

For 137 years, the construction of Barcelona's Sagrada Familia had been carried out illegally. That all changed on Friday after the Catholic church finally received its building permit, according to a city official. The designer, Catalan modernist Antoni Gaud√≠, had asked for a permit in 1885 but never received an answer, according to the church. And even though construction of the neo-Gothic church began in 1882, authorities only discovered in 2016 that it never had planning permission, AFP reported. Architects have worked to finish the church according to Gaud√≠'s original design, and work is scheduled to end in 2026, marking 100 years since his death. About 4.5 million people visit the unfinished basilica every year.
(üì∏: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

''This award is for every kid who is watching tonight who has a disability, who has a limitation or a challenge, who has been waiting to see themselves represented in this arena ‚Äî you are." Ali Stroker made history as the first actor in a wheelchair to ever win a Tony Award. She took home the award for featured actress in a musical for her role in "Oklahoma!‚Äù
#tonyawards @alistroker (üì∏: Theo Wargo/Getty Images for Tony Awards Production)

More than a million people took part in a massive protest in Hong Kong on Sunday, organizers said, standing against a controversial bill that would enable China to extradite fugitives from the city. Hong Kong Police, however, estimated the number of protesters as closer to 240,000. Critics say the bill will leave anyone on Hong Kong soil vulnerable to being grabbed by the Chinese authorities for political reasons. The protest was mostly peaceful during the day, with a vast march stretching across the city and ending at the government‚Äôs headquarters. However, the demonstration turned violent overnight, with police trying to clear protesters with batons and pepper spray. The government of Hong Kong released a statement late on Sunday acknowledging the ongoing protests across the island, but reiterating that the extradition bill is still scheduled to resume debate on June 12. üì∏ @taramulholland / CNN

This month, you‚Äôll be able to see Jupiter and its largest moons with just binoculars. The planet "is at its biggest and brightest this month," according to NASA.  Jupiter, the largest planet in the solar system, will be most visible on June 10, and from June 14-19 there will be a "beautiful lineup" of the Moon, Jupiter and Saturn. (üì∏: NASA)

This futuristic concept plane, the ‚ÄúFlying-V,‚Äù which puts passengers in its wings, aims to change the way we fly. The plan is designed to be 20% more fuel-efficient than the popular Airbus A350, while still carrying more than 300 passengers. "Aviation is contributing about 2.5% of global CO2 emissions, and the industry is still growing, so we really need to look at more sustainable airplanes," said project leader Roelof Vos, a researcher at Delft University of Technology in the Netherlands. For more, follow @cnnclimate. (üì∏: KLM)

Nike‚Äôs flagship London store on Wednesday unveiled its first plus-size and para-sport mannequins, along with an ‚Äúextended offering‚Äù of plus-size items. A spokeswoman for Nike said the redesigned space reflects the company‚Äôs ‚Äúcommitment to inspiring and serving the female athlete." For more, follow @cnnstyle and @cnnbusiness.(üì∏: Nike)

Fancy a dip with a view? This 600,000-liter pool, which will sit atop a 55-story building in London, is being touted as the world‚Äôs first rooftop infinity pool. Its designer, Compass Pools, says swimmers üèä‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èwill access the pool via a spiral staircase that rotates and rises through the water. (üì∏: Compass Pools)

CNN‚Äôs @arwacnn joined a team of scientists in the Fram Strait, near Greenland, to try to investigate what‚Äôs causing the Arctic to heat up two times faster than the global average. For more about her trip and #WorldOceansDay, tap the link in our bio. For more, follow @cnnclimate)

Isaiah Tuckett, a 14-year-old from Minnesota, has dreamed of going to Disney World for as long as he could remember. To pay for it, Isaiah began selling cupcakes üßÅand after a year of saving, he‚Äôd made enough profit to send his family of seven to Orlando for six nights. Isaiah said the trip was ‚Äúreally exciting and warm‚Äù and he is continuing to sell his cupcakes‚Äî$20 for a dozen‚Äîto save up for a blue Ford pickup truck when he gets his license. (üì∏: Cheri Tuckett)

Two women say they were beaten and robbed by a group of men in a homophobic attack on a London bus. One of the women, Melania Geymonat, posted this photo on Facebook of herself and her girlfriend covered in blood, along with her account of the assault. "They started behaving like hooligans, demanding that we kissed so they could enjoy watching..." she said in the post. London police said they are investigating the attack.
(üì∏: Melania Geymonat/Facebook)

In honor of Pride month, the New York state Capitol raised a rainbow LGBTQ pride flag üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåàalongside the state flag for the first time. ‚ÄúNew York is home to trailblazing leaders in the LGBTQ rights movement who broke down barriers and never stopped fighting for full equality,‚Äù New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo said. (üì∏: NYGovCuomo/Twitter)

These rare archive photos offer a glimpse of what the D-Day invasion of Normandy, the largest seaborne invasion in history, looked like from the Allies' perspective. When the Allies launched the battle 75 years ago, on June 6, 1944, military leaders knew it would be a turning point in the fight against Nazi Germany, so they documented it extensively. Professional photographers were embedded in various units, even some on the front lines. "This visual record brings it all to life and it really does put it into perspective," says Anthony Richards, head of documents and sound at the Imperial War Museum in England. "They help us engage with history and put ourselves in the place of those soldiers."
(üì∏: Imperial War Museum)

Drone video shows the French coast where, 75 years ago, tens of thousands of Allied troops landed in Normandy to confront Nazi forces in the largest amphibious assault ever launched. The invasion on June 6, 1944, known as D-Day, laid the foundations for the Allied defeat of Germany in World War II. On this day alone, 4,414 Allied troops were confirmed dead, with more than 9,000 wounded or missing. The precise number of German deaths isn't known, but they are estimated to be between 4,000 and 9,000.

Imagine being 97 years old and flinging yourself from a plane above Normandy, France. World War II veteran Tom Rice did just that. He marked the 75th anniversary of D-Day by reliving the time he nearly died jumping from a C-47 Douglas airplane and then was shot at, again and again. This time, he reached the ground with only a slight stumble on impact, saying he felt "great" and was ready to "go back up and do it again."
üÜï Tap on our Story to see more from Rice's jump.
(üì∏: Ludovic Marin/AFP/Getty Images)

At just 31 years old, Rihanna is officially the richest female musician in the world, according to Forbes, which estimated her net worth at a staggering $600 million üí∞That's about $30 million more than Madonna, and $200 million more than Beyonc√©. According to Forbes, the majority of RiRi's income comes from her partnership with LVMH, the French luxury goods company that launched her fashion label Fenty last month (üì∏: Theo Wargo/Getty Images)

More than 70 years after serving in World War II as a bombardier and pilot for the Army Air Forces, Walter Kloc traveled 1,500 miles to commission his grandson, Joseph, as an officer in the US Air Force. The Air Force Academy said that the crowd gave the veteran a standing ovation during the ceremony. On Facebook, Joseph Kloc said it was "probably one of the best days of my life."
(üì∏: US Air Force Academy)

London's Mayor Sadiq Khan compared Donald Trump to a young child after the US President called him a "stone-cold loser." "This is the sort of behavior I would expect from an 11-year-old," Khan said. Trump is in the UK for a state visit.

High school senior Leanne Carrasco (right) decided to forgo a graduation party and give back to her community in Houston. She enlisted her friends to help, and together they threw a pizza party at a homeless shelter for women and children. The teens also packed 400 hygiene bags filled with toothbrushes, toothpaste, hand wipes and deodorant to hand out to residents of the shelter. ‚ÄúNot a lot of people have the same options as me. It‚Äôs not fair,‚Äù Carrasco told CNN. ‚ÄúThere are a lot of people who need help. So I give it.‚Äù (üì∏: Courtesy of Leanne Carrasco)

Larry the Cat, the ‚Äúchief mouser‚Äù of the British prime minister‚Äôs residence, slipped past Secret Service to take up a position underneath President Trump‚Äôs heavily armored limousine, known as ‚ÄúThe Beast.‚Äù via @cnnpolitics (üì∏: Daniel Leal-Olivas/AFP/Getty Images)

Crowds gathered in Hong Kong on Tuesday for a candlelight vigil to mark the 30th anniversary of the deadly crackdown on pro-democracy activists in Beijing‚Äôs Tiananmen Square. The Chinese government never released an official death toll from the 1989 massacre, but human-rights groups estimate it was in the hundreds, if not thousands. Hong Kong, a semi-autonomous city, is the only place on Chinese soil where such massive, public commemorations are held. Within mainland China, all mentions of the crackdown have been erased from history books, and the internet is strictly censored. (üì∏: @joshcnn )

The world is marking the 30th anniversary of China‚Äôs Tiananmen Square massacre. Hundreds of people were killed on June 4, 1989, as People's Liberation Army troops cracked down on pro-democracy protesters in and around Beijing's Tiananmen Square. In the preceding weeks, hundreds of thousands of students and workers had gathered in the square to call for greater democracy, as well as political and social reforms. At the height of the protests, it seemed like they could be successful - but hardliners won an internal battle within the ruling Communist Party, and a crackdown was ordered. On the night of June 3, convoys of armed troops entered Beijing with an aim to clear the square by whatever means necessary. Witnesses told horrific stories of tanks driving over unarmed protesters and soldiers shooting indiscriminately into crowds. No official death toll was ever released by the Chinese government, but human rights groups estimate it was the hundreds, if not thousands. The events of June 4 have been wiped from the history books in China, and any discussion of the crackdown is strictly censored and controlled. On the 30th anniversary, no public memorials or events marking the day are expected in mainland China. Photos: Catherine Henriette / Sadayuki Mikami / AFP / Getty Images

A powerful new mural of 16-year-old climate activist @GretaThunberg was unveiled in Bristol, England, this week as part of Europe‚Äôs largest street art festival, @upfest . The artist, Jody Thomas, said "65%-70% of the wall was painted with water-based paint with an electric spray gun powered by the Tobacco Factories solar cells.‚Äù For more climate news, follow @cnnclimate (üì∏: @jody_artist )

Pomp and ceremony dominated as Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Charles welcomed President Trump and first lady Melania Trump to Buckingham Palace, launching the President's long-awaited state visit to the United Kingdom. (üì∏: Victoria Jones, Toby Melville/WPA Pool, Chris Jackson/Getty Images)

In her seven-decade culinary career, Leah Chase did far more than introduce thousands to Creole cuisine. She fed presidents and Freedom Riders. She broke New Orleans' segregation laws by seating black and white patrons together. And she helped mend the country's divisions, one meal at a time. The chef and civil rights activist died Saturday, her family said. She was 96 years old. "Her daily joy was not simply cooking, but preparing meals to bring people together,‚Äù her family said in a statement. (üì∏: Brent Humphreys/CNN)

Kindergartener Morey Belanger is the first deaf student to ever attend Dayton Consolidated School in Maine. To make her feel welcome, students have learned how to sign more than 20 words including colors, letters and words related to school. To celebrate their hard work, the school invited a princess who knows sign language to come speak to students. "Morey -- without even knowing it -- has taught us so much," said school Principal Kimberly Sampietro. "She has brought a culture to our building that we didn't have before."
(üì∏: Dayton Consolidated School)

Champions of Europe! üèÜ The streets of Liverpool were flooded with red on Sunday to celebrate Liverpool FC‚Äôs victory in the Champions League -- European football‚Äôs greatest prize. Players, staff and management rode three open-top buses around the UK city just hours after they arrived from Madrid, after beating Tottenham Hotspur 2-0 in the final. It is the sixth time Liverpool have won the competition, previously picking it up in 2005, 1977, 1978, 1981 and 1984. #liverpool #championsleague (üì∏:Oli Scarff/AFP/Getty Images, Anthony Devlin/AFP/Getty Images via @cnnsport)

Ahead of the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall riots, New York City announced it would honor two transgender activists for their lifelong commitment to LGBTQ rights. The statues of Marsha P. Johnson (right) and Sylvia Rivera, who were part of the 1969 uprising, will be the first in the US to honor transgender people, according to the New York Mayor‚Äôs office. The Stonewall riots‚Äîa series of violent confrontations between members of the gay community and police‚Äîare widely considered the catalyst to the modern gay rights movement in the US. (üì∏: Justin Sutcliffe/AP, Handout/Reuters)

Alabama Gov. Kay Ivey this week signed an order for monuments to be erected in honor of civil rights icon Rosa Parks and activist Helen Keller, both natives of the state. Parks famously refused to give up her seat on a Montgomery bus in 1955, which became a pivotal moment in the Civil Rights movement. Keller, who lost her sight and hearing as a toddler, went on to become a political activist, author and speaker. (üì∏: Getty Images/Hulton Archive)

Residents and a group of international academics are protesting plans to build an airport near Machu Picchu, the famed Inca ruins that are already grappling with overcrowding from tourists. In a petition, the group urges Peru‚Äôs president, Martin Vizcarra, to cancel the project, saying the airport "endangers the conservation of one of the most important historical and archaeological sites in the world." Vizcarra argues that the project will bring revenue to local communities without causing significant damage to the surrounding areas. (üì∏: Cris Bouroncle/AFP/Getty Images)

LaCroix was once the Millennial "it" brand in one of the fastest-growing parts of the beverage market. But bigger, deeper-pocketed companies have caught up and LaCroix's sales have fallen more than 15% in May. Sales for the flavored carbonated water are "effectively in free fall," wrote Laurent Grandet, a beverage analyst for Guggenheim. (üì∏: Getty Images/Justin Sullivan)

Can you spell H-I-S-T-O-R-Y? The 92nd Scripps National Spelling Bee had an epic ending with eight co-champions. The spelling bee was stopped after it went 20 rounds, which included a run of 47 correct words to end the competition. The Bee's official pronouncer called the group "the most phenomenal assemblage of super-spellers" in the competition's history - "We're throwing the dictionary at you and so far, you are showing the dictionary who is boss." Each of the eight champions will receive a $50,000 prize. (üì∏: Alex Wong/Getty Images)

New Hampshire repealed the death penalty Thursday after the state legislature voted to override a veto from GOP Gov. Chris Sununu, making it the 21st state to abolish the punishment in the US. The bill said a person convicted of a capital murder "shall be sentenced to imprisonment for life without the possibility for parole." (üì∏: Oliver Le Queinec/Shutterstock)

Friends of the late Anthony Bourdain have declared June 25 "Bourdain Day" to celebrate and remember the legendary chef and storyteller on his birthday. ‚ÄúAs you move through this life and this world you change things slightly, you leave marks behind, however small," Bourdain said. "And in return, life ‚Äî and travel ‚Äî leaves marks on you." For more, follow @cnntravel. (üì∏: Mario Tama/Getty Images for CNN)

Baby Saybie was born prematurely in December, weighing just 8.6 ounces - about the weight of a large apple ‚Äî making her the smallest surviving baby in the world, according to officials at Sharp Mary Birch Hospital. After nearly five months, she has left the hospital and weighs about 5.6 pounds. "After experiencing severe pregnancy complications, Saybie's mother gave birth via emergency cesarean section at 23 weeks, 3 days gestation in the womb," the hospital explained at a news conference.
(üì∏: Sharp Mary Birch Hospital for Women & Newborns)

A galaxy far, far away has come to Anaheim, California üí´ When Star Wars: Galaxy's Edge opens in Disneyland on Friday, guests will be able to take a ride on the Millennium Falcon, build their own lightsabers, eat fried Endorian tip-yip and drink Luke Skywalker's favorite beverage. The now functional, detailed and movie-accurate 14-acre playground is where millions of guests will start visiting on May 31. A second Galaxy's Edge is opening later this summer in Florida's Disney World. (üì∏: @michellegroskopf for CNN; Todd Wawrychuk, Joshua Sudock/Disney Parks) #galaxysedge

Alex Trebek, who announced in March that he had been diagnosed with stage 4 pancreatic cancer, told People magazine that he‚Äôs in ‚Äúnear remission,‚Äù according to his doctors. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs kind of mind-boggling,‚Äù the 78-year-old TV host said. ‚ÄúThe doctors said they hadn‚Äôt seen this kind of positive result in their memory ‚Ä¶ some of the tumors have already shrunk by more than 50%.‚Äù The survival rate for those with Trebek‚Äôs kind of cancer is about 9%. (üì∏: Amanda Edwards/Getty Images)

In a rare and remarkable public statement, special counsel Robert Mueller said his investigation could not clear President Donald Trump, and that charging the President was "not an option." The statement was Mueller's first public comment on the investigation since he was appointed special counsel two years ago. "If we had confidence that the President clearly did not commit a crime, we would have said so," Mueller said. "We did not however make a determination as to whether the President did commit a crime."
(üì∏: Mandel Ngan/Getty Images/AFP)

This Oregon church turns heads with its street signs that slam white supremacy, back transgender rights and urge tolerance toward Muslims. "People are thirsty to know they are loved," said Rev. Adam Ericksen, the pastor at Clackamas United Church of Christ. Drivers honk in support as they go by, and the signs have a been a huge hit on social media, some getting more than 10,000 shares on Facebook. "We've gotten hundreds of messages, including from transgender people who say they wish they had a church like this in their area," Ericksen said.

‚ÄúI have a disproportionate amount of money to share,‚Äù MacKenzie Bezos said in a letter announcing that she would give away at least half her wealth. She became one of the richest people in the world following her divorce from Amazon founder Jeff Bezos and is now worth an estimated $36.6 billion. "My approach to philanthropy will continue to be thoughtful. It will take time and effort and care. But I won't wait. And I will keep at it until the safe is empty,‚Äù Bezos wrote. (üì∏:Dia Dipasupil/Getty Images)

Eighty years ago, Helen Danis couldn‚Äôt afford to attend her prom. "I couldn't keep up with the kids," Danis told CNN affiliate WJAR. "I didn't really fit in. We were in the middle of a depression and money was scarce." But her granddaughter Julie Huddon has been helping her grandmother check things off her bucket list. Huddon got permission from Pilgrim High School, in Warwick, Rhode Island, to have her 97-year-old grandmother attend the prom as her date. Danis danced the night away doing the Hully Gully, the Cupid Shuffle and the Cha-Cha Slide. (üì∏: Sam Read/WJAL)

People in western Ohio are cleaning up after severe storms and tornadoes left swaths of devastation. At least three tornadoes are believed to have caused damage Monday night, including one in the city of Celina, where one man was killed and seven others were injured, Mayor Jeff Hazel said. One resident of Brookville, which is northwest of Dayton, described the scene: "We went out in the streets and children were screaming and crying. Devastation everywhere." (üì∏: Jake Carpenter, Doral Chenoweth III/The Columbus Dispatch Gia AP, Seth Herald/AFP/Getty Images, John Minchillo/AP, Matthew Hatcher/Getty Images)

Sully, the former service dog üê∂ to the late President George H.W. Bush, returned to the spotlight this week with a #MemorialDay message. ‚ÄúAlways thinking of my best friend & the bravest military in the world who made the ultimate sacrifice while defending our country for our freedoms,‚Äù reads the pup‚Äôs Instagram post, which accompanied this photo. The caption also quoted Bush, who served in the military before he became president: ‚ÄúEach of the patriots whom we remember on this day was first a beloved son or daughter, a brother or sister, or a spouse, friend, and neighbor.‚Äù (üì∏: @sullyhwbush)

This 2-year-old boy has hypotonia, a syndrome that impacts his muscle tone and makes it hard to get around. When Logan's parents walked into Home Depot looking for supplies for a DIY walker, employees went above and beyond. They built him a walker out of PVC pipes and put his name on it. They refuse to accept a dime. "I couldn't believe they were willing to do that. It took everything I had not to cry because it hasn't been an easy road for my son. He has had a hard time doing things that would be easy for most children his age," Logan's mother, Christian Moore.
(üì∏: Christian Moore)

These two veterans had to leave high school early to enter the military. Now they're both joining the graduating class of 2019. ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Joe Perricone (left), 95, was drafted to serve in the US Army in World War II in 1943. Although he received a diploma, he never got to walk for graduation, he told CNN affiliate WFLA. More than 70 years later, his grandson worked with the school to arrange for his grandfather to walk with the class of 2019. ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä At 16, Bill William Arnold Craddock (right), 85, joined the Air Force without graduating. Craddock told CNN affiliate WJHL that he did complete his GED but never got to walk in a graduation. Now, 66 years later, he has made that dream a reality. "It means a lot to me... I'm tickled pink I went through this to get this," Craddock told WJHL. (üì∏: WFLA/WJHL)

Seeing double? Meet Deontae Wright (left), the valedictorian for the class of 2019 at Scott High School in Toledo, Ohio. With a grade-point average of 4.5, he just edged out his main competition for the top spot, his identical twin brother, Deontre (right), who was close on his heels with a 4.4 GPA, making him salutatorian. "Our biggest thing is competing against each other," Deontre says. "We ended up having a competition all throughout high school to see who would do better."
(üì∏: Victoria Lampkin)

Erica Alfaro honored her parents in her graduation photos, standing in her cap and gown in the middle of the fruit fields where her mother still works. "With love I dedicate my master's to my parents. Their sacrifice to come to this country to give us a better future was well worth it," Alfaro said. Her parents are farmers who were never able to go to school, and she credits her mother's advice on education as her inspiration for going back to school. On May 19, Alfaro graduated from San Diego State University with a master's degree in education. She hopes the photos inspire people from the Latino community who face similar struggles. "These photos represent many of us," she said. "Our parents came to this country to give us a better life and we wouldn't be here without them." (üì∏: Infro Photography By Aldair Sanchez)

Good boy, Spyke! A drug task force officer and his K-9 partner tracked down a stash of more than 60 pounds of cocaine with a street value of $1.4 million in the Houston area this week. Police arrested a 50-year-old suspect on two felony charges. (üì∏: Fort Bend County Sheriff's Office)

Disney is picking up the tab for workers to attend the University of Central Florida, covering 100% of tuition upfront. Disney will also reimburse funds spent on application fees, books and course materials. About 40% of the company‚Äôs 85,000 full-time and part-time hourly employees have signed up, and 6,000 are already taking classes, according to UCF. (üì∏: Getty Images)

Mr. Rogers had a special code to let the people in his neighborhood know that he cared: ‚Äú1-4-3,‚Äù or the number of letters in the words ‚ÄúI love you.‚Äù Now, the Pennsylvania native who starred in ‚ÄúMister Rogers‚Äô Neighborhood,‚Äù will be honored by his home state with ‚Äú143 Day,‚Äù on May 23 ‚Äî the 143rd day of the year. (üì∏: Fotos International/Archive Photos/Getty Images)

This (very extra) hotel wants you to know it‚Äôs ready to rock üé∏ The 400-foot tall Hard Rock property in Hollywood, Florida, claims to be the world‚Äôs first guitar-shaped hotel and features, as you might have guessed, rock-and-roll elements, including Elvis Presley‚Äôs gold-plated piano and a large music venue. The hotel will open this fall, with room bookings starting in July. (üì∏: Seminole Hard Rock Hotel & Casino) @cnntravel #cnntravel

More than 1,000 participants attended a wedding banquet held by #Taiwan LGBTQ rights activists to celebrate some of the first legally recognized same-sex marriages on the island. The event in Taipei included a joint wedding for about 20 couples and stage performances, including a drag act. üì∏: Tyrone Siu/Reuters, Ritchie B. Tongo/EPA/Shutterstock, Sam Yeh/AFP/Getty Images

When Frank Baez was 17, he worked as a hospital janitor at New York University, mopping floors and cleaning patients‚Äô rooms. This week, the 29-year-old got his nursing degree from NYU‚Äôs college of nursing. Baez, who came to the US when he was 15, is the first in his family to graduate from college. ‚ÄúIt was a lot of work,‚Äù Baez said. ‚ÄúIt was worth it ‚Äì it paid off at the end. Here I am, a graduated nurse."(üì∏: New York University)

Hundreds of thousands of students walked out of classes on Friday to raise the alarm over #climatechange üåç Protests were planned in more than 125 countries and organizers expected more than 1.6 million people who take part. The movement was inspired by 16-year-old Swedish activist @gretathunberg who last year began skipping school to protest outside the Swedish parliament. Above, students protest in Auckland, New Zealand; Kiev, Ukraine; Bordeaux, France; Madrid; Berlin; Frankfurt and Delhi. For more, follow @cnnclimate. (üì∏: Hannah Peters, NurPhoto, Juan Pelegr√≠n Corbacho, Picture Alliance/Getty Images, Charansh Juneja)

In a blow to LGBTQ rights, Kenya's highest court ruled Friday that a colonial-era law banning same-sex relations should remain in place. Anyone found engaging in same-sex relationships could face up to 14 years in prison. Kenya is not alone in its decision ‚Äî 38 of 55 African countries have laws that make it illegal to be gay, and it‚Äôs punishable by death in Somalia and South Sudan. (üì∏: Yasuyoshi China/AFP/Getty Images)

Beaming in the bright sunshine, Amber Wang and Kristin Huang made history as one of the first same-sex couples to marry in Asia. The two women, who co-host a YouTube channel called BBDiary, officially became wife and wife just days after Taiwan passed a historical same-sex marriage law. "I'm so proud that Taiwan is on the right side of the history and the first in Asia to have done so ... Taiwan has set an example in making progress in safeguarding human rights," Huang said.

UK Prime Minister Theresa May choked up as she announced her resignation Friday morning. "I will shortly leave the job that it has been the honor of my life to hold," she said. May was forced into making Friday's announcement after losing the support of her Cabinet, many of whom were fed up with the ongoing turmoil over Brexit. May said she would quit as leader of the Conservative Party on June 7, but would stay on as Prime Minister until a successor is chosen. (üì∑ Leon Neal/Getty Images)

Two people died after crowds of mountaineers got stuck in a traffic jam near the summit of Mount Everest. This extraordinary photo, posted by climber Nirmal Purja, shows a dense trail of people queuing on an exposed ridge to reach the top of the world‚Äôs highest mountain. Purja said there were roughly 320 people in the queue to the summit in an area known as the "death zone," where each breath contains only one-third of the oxygen found at sea level. (üì∑ Project Possible via AFP/Getty Images)

President Trump and first lady Melania Trump paid their respects to fallen American troops during an unannounced visit to Arlington National Cemetery on Thursday. The first couple, who spent about 20 minutes at the military cemetery, laid flags on the headstones. The visit comes ahead of Memorial Day weekend, which the President will spend in Japan. (üì∏: Bloomberg via Getty Images)

An artist in Australia unveiled an 80-foot mural depicting New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern embracing a woman in a hijab in the wake of the mosque shootings in Christchurch that left 51 dead. The work was created by painter Loretta Lizzio and financed by a GoFundMe campaign, which called Ardern a ‚Äúbeacon of tolerance, love and peace in these divisive times.‚Äù Lizzio told CNN affiliate 7 News the mural ‚Äúcelebrates a moment of unity and compassion." (üì∏: Recap Sakar/Andalou Agency/Getty Images, Hagen Hopkins/Getty Images Asiapac)

In an effort to curb ocean pollution, officials in England are banning plastic straws, stirrers and cotton buds, aka Q-Tips, starting in April 2020. The government estimates that about 4.7 billion plastic straws, 316 million plastic stirrers and 1.8 billion plastic-stemmed cotton buds are used in England each year. ‚ÄúUrgent and decisive action is needed to tackle plastic pollution and protect our environment,‚Äù said Environment Secretary Michael Gove. The governments of Scotland and Wales are considering similar measures. For more, follow @cnnclimate. (üì∏:Phatthanit/Shutterstock)

Washington just became the first state to legalize the composting of human bodies as an alternative to burial or cremation. In composting, which advocates say is an environmentally friendly process, a body is "covered in natural materials, like straw or wood chips, and over the course of about three to seven weeks...it breaks down into soil," says Katrina Spade, CEO of the human composting company Recompose. Above, Spade is pictured in a Seattle cemetery holding a sample of compost material left from the decomposition of a cow. To learn more, follow @cnnclimate. (üì∏: Elaine Thompson/AP)

Braxton Moral graduated from his high school in Kansas on Sunday, and on May 30, the 17-year-old is set to receive his undergraduate degree from Harvard University. Moral's parents enrolled him in Harvard Extension School when he was just 11, he told CNN. "My parents noticed I was bored in school and needed something to inspire growth, so they ended up finding the Extension School," he said. The busy teen isn't slowing down now; he plans on attending law school and is currently writing a book.
(üì∏: Mandy Moral/Facebook)

A record-breaking spring storm dumped three inches of snow around the Denver airport on Tuesday, and other parts of the state got as much as six inches of snow. Believe it or not, it's not unusual for it to snow in the Mile High City this late in the season. Denver averages around one inch of snow during the month of May, and it has snowed during May in 52 of the last 70 years. (üì∏: Jerilee Bennett/The Gazette via AP)

Across the US on Tuesday, abortion-rights advocates flooded town squares and statehouses, chanting and carrying signs to protest new state laws that criminalize or sharply restrict abortions. "Across the country, we are seeing a new wave of extreme bans on abortion, stripping away reproductive freedom and representing an all-out assault on abortion access," organizers said. Using the hashtag #StopTheBans, the protesters spoke up for reproductive freedom.
(üì∏: Matt Rourke/AP, Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/AFP/Getty Images, Elijah Nouvelage/Getty Images, Kevin Lamarque/Reuters and CNN‚Äôs @kokomodianne)

Elmo has a new friend on ‚ÄúSesame Street‚Äù named Karlie, and she‚Äôs helping highlight the stories of foster families. Karli's appearances contain lessons for foster families -- like the importance of stability and a sense of belonging -- as well as explanations for children, told through the eyes of Elmo. May is National Foster Care Month in the US, and there are more than 440,000 children and youth in foster care, according to the US Department of Health and Human Service's Children's Bureau.
(üì∏: @sesamestreet) #sesamestreet

One of motor racing's greatest drivers has died. Niki Lauda was a three-time Formula One champion with Ferrari and McLaren in 1975, 1977 and 1984 -- with two of the wins coming after a crash that almost cost him his life. At the 1976 German Grand Prix, Lauda collided with a barrier and his car went up in flames. He inhaled toxic fumes and suffered horrific burns that left him close to death and with permanent facial scaring. Nevertheless, he returned to racing just six weeks later. Lauda died on Monday at the age of 70 following a period of declining health. In a 2016 interview with CNN, Lauda warned that introducing too many safety measures would damage Formula One. "My opinion is, if we continue only to think of making it 110% about the safety issues, we're going to destroy Formula One." (üì∏: ERWIN SCHERIAU/AFP/Getty Images via @cnnsport)

Pedestrians could soon be fined between $25 and $250 for using portable electronic devices while crossing the road, thanks to a bill in the New York State Senate. The statewide ban would include texting, checking emails, browsing the internet, with exceptions for emergencies. Honolulu passed a similar law in 2017 ‚Äî which appeared to be the first of its kind ‚Äî known as the ‚Äúdistracted pedestrian‚Äù law. (üì∏: Getty Images)

Britain‚Äôs Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis are growing up fast ‚Äî and Kensington Palace has released adorable new photos of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge playing with their children, in a new garden co-designed by the Duchess. The "Back to Nature" garden, also designed by architects Andr√©e Davies and Adam White, will be unveiled at the Chelsea Flower Show in London, which starts on Tuesday. The space, which features swing sets, a treehouse and a river, is aimed at getting children to go outside and play, and is part of the Duchess‚Äô work on children‚Äôs early development. And judging by the royal children‚Äôs muddy frolicking, it‚Äôs a hit. (üì∏: Matt Porteus/AP)

üö®Cool job alert üö®Buckingham Palace is hiring a social media pro to find ‚Äúnew ways to maintain the Queen‚Äôs presence in the public eye and on the world stage.‚Äù The role, which will involve covering state visits, writing articles and managing digital platforms, pays about $38,000 per year and comes with benefits üëë(üì∏: Getty Images)

About 30 million light-years from Earth, two galaxies came together in an epic collision, and the beautiful fallout was captured by the Hubble Space Telescope ‚ú®The impact created the blue stars and pink nebulas that can be seen on the right side of this image. Galaxy NGC 4485 and its larger galactic neighbor, NGC 4490, probably collided millions of years ago, but because it was so far away, we‚Äôre just seeing it now.(üì∏: ESA/Hubble/NASA)

Actress Maisie Williams recently opened up about how fame has had a negative effect on her mental health and self-esteem. Williams, who was 13 when she was cast as Arya Stark in #GameofThrones, told the Happy Place podcast about how she struggles with reading criticism on social media. ‚ÄúIt gets to a point where you're almost craving something negative, so you can just sit in a hole of sadness," she said. (üì∏: HBO)

A painting from Claude Monet‚Äôs ‚ÄúHaystacks‚Äù series set a record on Tuesday when it sold for $110.7 million üé®The painting, which went to an anonymous bidder, is the most expensive impressionist artwork ever to be bought at auction, according to Sotheby‚Äôs in New York. The 1890 painting is regarded as the best of the artist‚Äôs "Les Meules" series, the auction house said. Only four artworks from the 25-piece series have appeared at auction this century, and just eight remain in private hands. (üì∏: Courtesy of Sotheby‚Äôs via AP)

When India Jackson (left) was given the opportunity to work as an intern at @NASA, she wasn‚Äôt sure she could afford it. Jackson, who balances raising her preteen daughter (right) with working toward a PhD in solar physics at Georgia State University, thought the move to Houston would be too expensive. That‚Äôs when her cousin set up a GoFundMe campaign, and money flooded in. The campaign stopped taking donations after reaching its $8,000 goal in just one day. "This is amazing, an amazing opportunity, a lifetime dream," Jackson said. "I just didn't know how I would do it." (üì∏: India Jackson)

Floyd‚Äôs Pelican Bar, a wooden shack in Jamaica that is only accessible by boat, is hiring. After nearly 18 years of pulling pints, owner Floyd Forbes is taking a break and needs someone to fill in for him this summer. Interested? The job requires chatting with customers, serving pi√±a coladas and rum punches üçπand ‚Äúthrowing the occasional fish to the resident pelicans.‚Äù (üì∏: Courtesy Joe Pepler/Pinpep)
Swipe through ‚û°Ô∏è if you‚Äôve ever wondered what happens to your plastic when you recycle it ‚ôªÔ∏è For more, follow @cnnclimate.

Jessica Cox can fly a plane, scuba dive, and do taekwondo, even though she was born without arms. Cox, who has been flying since 2005, is certified by the Federal Aviation Administration to fly an Ercoup ‚Äî a small sport plane. "There were a lot of doubters on whether this was possible,‚Äù Cox said. But she credits her success to her family: "They helped me to really be encouraged to go out there and try it out, to figure things out and want to be independent." (üì∏: fearlessjessica.com)

Grumpy Cat, arguably the internet's most popular cat and one of its first viral memes, has died at age 7. "Despite care from top professionals, as well as from her very loving family, Grumpy encountered complications from a recent urinary tract infection that unfortunately became too tough for her to overcome," Grumpy Cat's owner said. The cat's real name was Tardar Sauce and she had feline dwarfism. This, her owners said, probably accounted for her distinctive facial features and small size. Her fame may have started on Reddit, but she became such a cultural phenomenon that she inspired art projects, perfumes, merchandise, Skechers shoes, comics and even a "Grumppuccino" coffee. At the time of her death, #grumpycat had 1.5 million followers on Twitter, 2.4 million on Instagram and 8.5 million on Facebook. "Grumpy Cat has helped millions of people smile all around the world -- even when times were tough. Her spirit will continue to live on through her fans everywhere," her owners said. (üì∏: David Livingston/Getty Images)

It's a historic day for the LGBT community in Asia. Taiwan lawmakers have approved a bill legalizing same-sex marriage, a landmark decision that makes it the first place in Asia to pass gay marriage legislation. The vote came almost two years after the island's Constitutional Court ruled that the existing law -- which said marriage was between a man and a woman -- was unconstitutional. The new law goes into effect on May 24. After the vote, Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen tweeted: "We took a big step towards true equality, and made Taiwan a better country." (üì∏: Sam Yeh/AFP/Getty Images)

I.M. Pei, the acclaimed architect who designed the Louvre's pyramid, has died at the age of 102. Although he worked mostly in the United States, Pei will always be remembered for a European project: his redevelopment of the #louvre Museum in Paris in the 1980s. He gave us the glass and metal pyramid in the main courtyard, along with three smaller pyramids and a vast subterranean addition to the museum entrance. Some of his other major commissions included the Bank of China Tower in Hong Kong and the Museum of Islamic Art in Qatar. Winning the fifth Pritzker Architecture Prize in 1983, Pei was cited as giving the 20th century "some of its most beautiful interior spaces and exterior forms ... His versatility and skill in the use of materials approach the level of poetry." (üì∏: Bertrand Guay/AFP/Getty Images, Anat Givon/Associated Press, Karim Jaafar/AFP/Getty Images, Paul Hawthorne/Getty Images via @cnnstyle)

These cadets are among the largest class of black women ever to graduate from West Point. The United States Military Academy said 34 black women are expected to walk across the stage at next week's graduation ceremony. The class of 2018 had 27 black women, and next year‚Äôs class is expected to be even larger, a spokesman said. (üì∏: West Point)

"Australia experienced a massacre and changed their laws. New Zealand had its experience and changed its laws. To be honest, I do not understand the United States," New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern told CNN‚Äôs @camanpour on Wednesday. Ardern announced a ban on military-style semiautomatic weapons, assault rifles and high-capacity magazines just days after the March 15 mosque shootings that killed 51 people.

Alabama's near-total ban on abortion was passed late Tuesday by a group of 25 male Republican state senators. Just six state senators, all Democrats, voted against it. The legislation, which now awaits the governor's signature, could punish doctors who perform abortions with life in prison, and bans the procedure in nearly all cases, including for victims of rape and incest. Three state senators didn't vote or weren't present, and one abstained.
Bill Nye is done mincing words about global warming. Follow @cnnclimate to learn more about what the Science Guy said about the state of the planet. (üì∏: John Lamparski/Getty Images)

A high school student wants to use her graduation cap to remember those teenagers who missed their own graduations because they were victims of mass shootings. Gina Warren of Ohio decorated her cap with a QR code that sends people who scan it with their phones to a list of students killed in US high schools. "This is mostly about honoring these kids," Warren said. "I want more than anything to keep their memory alive. But looking at that list, I'm hoping that everyone is touched and sees that there is a serious, serious problem in our country." Warren is planning to wear the cap at her graduation ceremony Sunday.
(üì∏: Gina Warren)

NASA plans to send the first woman and next man to the moon in a new mission called Artemis, named after the Greek goddess of the moon and twin sister of Apollo. The Apollo 11 mission succeeded in landing the first humans on the moon on July 20, 1969. Only 12 humans have ever walked on the moon and they were all male and all American, NASA says. President Trump announced Monday that he is adding $1.6 billion to NASA's budget "so that we can return to Space in a BIG WAY!" He challenged the agency to land at the south pole of the moon by 2024.
(üì∏: Twitter/Dennis Doucet)

üé∂ ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a simple message and it comes from the heart.‚Äù Arthur‚Äôs Mr. Ratburn has come out as gay in the new season of the PBS animated series. The show, which first aired in 1996, is back for its 22nd season and features a bespectacled aardvark called Arthur. In the episode ‚ÄúMr Ratburn and the Special Someone,‚Äù Arthur‚Äôs third grade teacher marries another male character. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a brand new world!‚Äù one of the students says during the wedding. (üì∏: PBS kids) #arthur

An infamously pungent fruit prompted the evacuation of a university library in Australia. About 550 people were forced to leave the University of Canberra building due to a suspected gas leak, but a search revealed the stench was instead caused by a durian fruit, the library said in a Facebook post. The spiky fruit's flavor and creamy texture has made it popular throughout southeast Asia, but its strong odor, which some critics have likened to rotten food or dirty socks, has gained it many detractors. (üì∏: Romeo Gacad/AFP/Getty Images)

This mom is on a mission to redefine the public perception of a woman's postpartum body. Mother and blogger Meg Boggs felt like she couldn't find images of other pregnant or postpartum women who looked like her on social media. "I felt as if my postpartum journey and body didn't count." After posting photos of herself, she asked other mothers to share their experiences with body image issues, postpartum depression and anxiety, and infant loss and grief using the hashtag #This_is_postpartum on Instagram. Sometimes, there are people that try to bring them down but Boggs says that, "I can get hundreds of negative comments but it's that one message that I'll get, even if it's just the one that says 'This is what I needed to see today,' it's those messages that remind me that it's worth it."
(üì∏: @meg.boggs, @asekyb, @thecrunchymommy, @denupzter, @zarubalife, @cbchatman, @thebirdspapaya, @sidelinesocialite @meghanjoytoday, and @thegarciadiaries)

After more than four months at sea, a 72-year-old French man completed his 2,930-mile trip across the Atlantic Ocean in a giant orange barrel he built himself. Jean-Jacques Savin set off from the Canary Islands in December and arrived in the Caribbean in May. He traveled about two miles an hour with no engine by relying entirely on the ocean current to guide his journey. "Everything has an end ... finally, here I am at the end of this adventure," he wrote on Facebook, after stepping foot on land for the first time this year.
(üì∏: Georges Gobet/APF/Getty Images and Lionel Chamoiseau/AFP/Getty Images)

A pilot in Myanmar is being hailed a hero for landing a plane on only its rear wheels after the passenger jet‚Äôs landing gear failed. Myanmar Airlines Flight 103 was headed from Yangon to Mandalay when the pilot discovered a problem. In a statement, the airline said pilot Captain Myat Moe Aung ‚Äúfollowed emergency procedures and did the fuel burn out to reduce the landing weight‚Äù before bringing the jet down on to its rear wheels, lowering the nose carefully onto the runway on which it skidded for about 25 seconds before stopping. There were no casualties or injuries from the incident. ‚ÄúThe pilot did a great job,‚Äù Myanmar‚Äôs transport minister said. (üì∏: Myanmar National Airlines/Facebook)

Japan on Friday began testing on the ALFA-X version of the Shinkansen bullet train, which is expected to be rolled out in 2030. The train‚Äôs operator says it will run at speeds of up to 224 mph, outpacing China‚Äôs Fuxing train, which runs at about 6 mph slower despite being designed with the same top speed capabilities. (üì∏: East Japan Railway Company)

Archaeologists recently stumbled upon a secret, 2,000-year-old underground room while working on a restoration project on the Roman Emperor Nero‚Äôs palace. Inside, they found colorful frescoes depicting a centaur and a man being attacked by a panther, the Archeological Park of the Coliseum said. (üì∏: Ufficio Stampa Parco Archeologico Del Colosseo)

This former NASA employee packed up her California life at the age of 24 to chase her dream of working at a bookshop in Scotland. (üì∏: Wigtown Festival Company and AirBnb/The Open Book)

Kwame Brathwaite‚Äôs photographs capture black creativity and expression in its purest and most candid of forms. Between the late 1950s and the late 1970s, Brathwaite made his career documenting the burgeoning black art and political movements in New York ‚Äî notably the "Black is Beautiful" campaign that encouraged black people to accept and celebrate their natural features. His photographs of black women in particular challenged the era's monolithic white beauty standards. (üì∏: Kwame Brathwaite/Philip Martin Gallery, Los Angeles)

"Born into captivity in Boston. Came to her freedom in Andover. Known by God and her community." Last fall, a group of Massachusetts high school students were assigned a project to uncover Foster‚Äôs story. Eventually, the students decided to raise money to give Foster a headstone. (üì∏: WCVB)

There's helium shortage on Earth, and that's bad news for balloons üéà Helium is the second-most abundant element in the galaxy, but Party City is struggling to find enough of the gas to fill its balloons‚Äîone of the company's most profitable services. Forty-five Party City locations will close this year as a result. Helium is a finite resource, and can be found in pockets buried under rock. (üì∏: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg via Getty Images)

A newly signed law in Georgia bans abortions in the state if a fetal heartbeat can be detected, which can be as early as six weeks into a pregnancy -- when many women don't yet know they're pregnant. Now, the heads of three production companies say they will not film in the state:

Instagram says it will block additional hashtags that spread misinformation about vaccines after @cnnbusiness found that some anti-vaccination accounts are still thriving on the platform despite a policy change. Instagram says the process for combating vaccine misinformation is ongoing and that Instagram is considering additional ways it can address the issue on the platform.

Scientists have repeatedly and consistently debunked the most common anti-vax myth, the idea that there is a connection between vaccinations and the development of autism in children. Reputable organizations like the American Medical Association and the American Academy of Pediatrics say that vaccination for children is crucial to public health.

More than 60 years after Autherine Lucy Foster made history as the first black student at the University of Alabama, she‚Äôs received an honorary doctorate from the school. Back in 1956, the college had to remove her from campus after only three days because of riots that broke out and death threats she received for being the first black person to go to a white school or university in the state. Last week, the 89-year-old was greeted by a standing ovation at the school‚Äôs graduation ceremony. "I wasn't crying, but tears was just rolling down my eyes because it's just so different and so unique for me to be able to come back to such a university as this," Foster told CNN affiliate WBRC. (üì∏: Zach Riggins/AP)

For the first time since 1882, when the first coal-fired power plant started running in the UK, the country has gone coal-free for a full week, according to the National Grid Electricity System Operator. "While this is the first time this has happened, I predict it will become the new normal," said Fintan Slye, director of the ESO. "We believe that by 2025 we will be able to fully operate Great Britain's electricity system with zero carbon." For more on renewable energy, follow @cnnclimate (üì∏: Andrew Aitchison/In Pictures via Getty Images)

Princess Margriet of the Netherlands gave Prince Harry a onesie for his newborn son as they marked the one-year countdown to the Invictus Games. (üì∏: Chris Jackson Pool/Getty Images)

The word "Responsibility" is missing an "i." Australia's Triple M radio station posted the mistake on its Instagram account, @mmmhotbreakfast. Denver has approved a city ordinance to decriminalize hallucinogenic mushrooms, the city's elections division said. Although it doesn't legalize the mushrooms, the ordinance would "prohibit the city from spending resources to impose criminal penalties" on those who have them. A range of mushroom species naturally contain the compound psilocybin, which has hallucinogenic properties. A growing body of medical research shows that psilocybin can treat conditions like anxiety and depression, in cases where drugs currently on the market cannot.
(üì∏: Getty Images)

‚ÄúI know that because of what he did, others are alive, and I thank God for that," says John Castillo, whose son, 18-year-old Kendrick Castillo, was killed in the shooting at STEM School Highlands Ranch on Tuesday. After Kendrick lunged at the shooter, three other students followed, tackling the gunman to allow the rest of the class to flee. Eight other students were shot but survived. "This wasn't your average kid," Kendrick‚Äôs father said. "He was extraordinary." (üì∏: Courtesy John and Maria Castillo)

Welcome to the world, Archie üéâ The Duke and Duchess of Sussex announced the name of their first born, Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor, on Wednesday. The couple also introduced Queen Elizabeth to her eighth great-grandchild at Windsor Castle, where Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, and Meghan's mother Doria Ragland were also present. ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
(üì∏: @sussexroyal /Chris Allerton)
