(üì∏: Slaven Vlasic/Getty Images for The Girls' Lounge)

üé∂ ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll never walk alone.‚Äù Liverpool Football Club's battle hymn rang out at their home ground Anfield with even more passion than usual on Wednesday night. Before the semifinal game against Barcelona last night, Liverpool were facing a 3-0 deficit and heading for an all-but-certain exit from the Champions League. But in a dramatic comeback in the second-leg tie, despite having key players missing through injury -- including Mo Salah and Roberto Firmino -- Liverpool overcame Lionel Messi‚Äôs Barcelona 4-0 and progressed on to the final. ‚ÄúWe played against maybe the best team in the world,‚Äù manager Jurgen Klopp said afterwards. ‚ÄúWinning is difficult, but winning with a clean sheet, I don‚Äôt know how they did it.‚Äù #liverpool #barcelona #championsleague (üì∏: Paul Ellis/AFP/Getty Images/Shaun Botterill/Clive Brunskill/Getty Images via @cnnsport)

When this Michigan mom learned she and her son would be graduating from different colleges on the same day, she decided to skip her graduation ceremony at Ferris State University to watch her son graduate from Central Michigan University. Upon hearing about Sharonda Wilson‚Äôs predicament, Central Michigan‚Äôs president contacted his counterpart at Ferris State, and the two hatched a plan to award Wilson her degree during her son‚Äôs graduation ceremony. "Earning my degree was such a huge milestone in my life, and having my mom with me to celebrate that moment was an unbelievable blessing,‚Äù said Wilson‚Äôs son. (üì∏: Central Michigan University)

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to get our friend back,‚Äù said high schooler Daphne Anselmo, who joined more than 100 students on Monday in a walkout to protest the arrest of an undocumented classmate. Just weeks before his graduation, Thomas Torres-Maytorena was turned over to federal authorities following a routine traffic stop on Thursday night, according to the sheriff‚Äôs department. His classmates staged the walkout in order to raise awareness about the arrest, a school spokesman told CNN affiliate KOLD. (üì∏: KOLD)

In an effort to curb CO2 emissions from diesel-powered trucks, Germany on Tuesday opened a roughly six-mile stretch of highway with overhead electric lines for big rigs. The system, which was developed by Siemens, allows trucks with special equipment to draw electric power from overhead cables. The trucks run on electric motors when connected to the overhead lines, and a hybrid system when they return to a traditional road. For more, go follow @cnnclimate. (üì∏: Picture Alliance/Getty Images)

Two Reuters journalists jailed in Myanmar for reporting on a massacre of Rohingya civilians have been freed after more than 500 days. Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo walked free on Tuesday just weeks after their final appeal was quashed. They were released as part of an amnesty of 6,520 prisoners by the country's President Win Myint. The two men, who received this year's Pulitzer Prize for International Reporting, have been locked up since December 2017, when they were charged under the country's colonial-era Official Secrets Act for allegedly disseminating secret information sensitive to national security. As he left the prison, Wa Lone said he was "really happy -- excited -- to see my family and colleagues. And I can't wait to go to my newsroom." üì∏ Myat Thu Kyaw/Getty Images

The #MetGala is known for delivering some of the most daring fashion statements of the year. This year's theme is "Camp: Notes on Fashion," and the charity benefit attracted a wide range of risqu√© looks. Lady Gaga had four outfit changes on the carpet while actor Billy Porter, decked all in gold, was carried in on a chaise by six shirtless men. The annual event at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York takes place on the first Monday of May and costs upwards of $30,000 a head to attend. (üì∏: Getty Images, AP, FilmMagic)

America‚Äôs top beauty pageants have, for the first time, crowned black women as their winners simultaneously. Chelsie Kryst (left) was named Miss USA on Thursday, while Kaliegh Garris became Miss Teen USA and Nia Franklin was named Miss America. Beauty pageants once barred women of color from participating, but in recent decades black women have broken down racial barriers in the pageant world. (üì∏: Frank L Szelwach/Miss Universe Organization/Lou Rocco/ABC via Getty Images)

Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, just gave birth to a baby boy. The Duchess and #royalbaby are both healthy and well, the couple said in an Instagram post. The baby, whose name hadn't been released, arrived Monday morning, weighing 7 pounds, 3 ounces. He is seventh in line to the British throne.
(üì∏:Dominic Lipinski/AFP/Getty Images/@sussexroyal)

A landmark United Nations report paints a bleak picture of our planet, with a growing human population whose consumption is destroying the natural world. Because of humans, 1 million of the Earth‚Äôs 8 million species are threatened with extinction, scientists warned in the report. Shrinking habitat, exploitation of natural resources, climate change and pollution are the main drivers of species loss. "It is not too late to make a difference, but only if we start now at every level from local to global," said Sir Robert Watson, the chairman of the UN committee behind the report, adding that "transformative change" is needed to save the planet. For more, follow @cnnclimate. (üì∏: Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund Intl/Zoological Society of London/Mark Kolbe/Getty Images)

If you‚Äôre afraid of heights, you might want to steer clear. The SkyBridge in Gatlinburg, Tennessee, which is the longest pedestrian suspension bridge in the US, will open on May 17. It stretches 680 feet across a valley in the Great Smokey Mountains and has glass-floor panels in the middle that allow you to see the ground 140 feet below. (üì∏: Boyne)

An 8-year-old British boy who was born without a right hand made history as the youngest and smallest person to be fitted with an advanced multi-grip bionic arm, according to manufacturer Open Bionics. The ‚ÄúHero Arm,‚Äù which translates electrical signals into a series of grips and movements, will help Freddie Payne pick up delicate objects, grip playground equipment and high-five his friends. Freddie‚Äôs mom said he was ‚Äúbeside himself with excitement‚Äù over the new arm and ‚Äúcouldn‚Äôt wait to move his fingers.‚Äù (üì∏: SWNS.com/SWNS-Cambridge)

If you want to ride the ‚ÄúYukon Striker,‚Äù prepare for the roller coaster to dangle you for three seconds 245 feet in the air, before it releases you into a vertical drop and a 360-degree loop. The ride, which goes up to 80 mph, opened on Friday in Canada‚Äôs Wonderland outside of Toronto, and the theme park says it‚Äôs ‚Äúthe longest, fastest and tallest dive roller coaster in the world.‚Äù (üì∏: Canada Wonderland)

We can now tell you how to get, how to get to Sesame Street üé∂In honor of the show‚Äôs 50th anniversary, New York made ‚ÄúSesame Street‚Äù a permanent intersection at the corner of West 63rd Street and Broadway. ‚ÄúFifty years of extraordinary programming, 50 years of making people's lives better, 50 years of helping children believe in themselves,‚Äù Mayor Bill de Blasio said during a ceremony on Wednesday, surrounded by Big Bird, Elmo Bert, Ernie and all the others. (üì∏: Richard Termin/Sesame Workshop)

Thailand is preparing for a $31 million three-day celebration to crown its new king. The 66-year-old King Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun ascended the throne more than two years ago following the death of his father, King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who was widely beloved and revered. Thailand's monarchy hasn't held absolute power in 86 years, but it remains an influential part of Thai life. (üì∏:Lauren DeCicca/Getty Images)

A team of volunteers has collected three tons ‚Äî that‚Äôs roughly the weight of two SUVs ‚Äî of garbage from the world‚Äôs highest peak in about two weeks, according to the Everest Cleaning Campaign. A helicopter helped to remove the trash, which included empty cans, bottles, plastic and discarded climbing gear. Four bodies were also located on the mountain. For more, go follow @cnnclimate. (üì∏: Prakash Mathema/AFP/Getty Images)

Riley Howell was killed Tuesday when a gunman opened fire on a classroom at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. The 21-year-old student, who was one of two people killed in the shooting, charged and knocked into the shooter, which police said helped save lives. "He did such a heroic thing," his aunt said. "He was everybody's protector. You felt safe when you were with Riley." (üì∏: Courtesy Morgan Howell Moylan)

Happy birthday, Princess Charlotte üéÇ Kensington Palace just released these birthday photos, taken by her mother, the Duchess of Cambridge, aka Kate Middleton. Charlotte's brother, Prince Louis, turned 1 last month.
(üì∏: Duchess of Cambridge/AP)

Police are investigating after someone burned dozens of beehives just south of Houston over the weekend. One of the beekeepers, who cares for the hives owned by the Brazoria County Beekeepers Association, said the loss is truly staggering: "We're looking at 500,000 to 600,000 [bees] that have been destroyed,‚Äù Steve Brackman told CNN affiliate KTRK. Brazoria County Crime Stoppers is offering a reward of up to $5,000 for information related to the crime, while the beekeepers association is offering a $1,000 reward and is asking for donations to help it recover. (üì∏: Brazoria County Crime Stoppers)

Parker Curry, the girl who was famously awestruck by Michelle Obama‚Äôs portrait, is preparing to release a book, ‚ÄúParker Looks Up,‚Äù in the fall. The picture of Parker, who was 2 years old at the time, staring up at painting at the National Portrait Gallery was shared widely after an onlooker posted it online last year, and Parker went on to meet and become friends with the former first lady. ‚ÄúThis book means so much to us and we hope that it inspires Parker's generation and generations to come," said Parker‚Äôs mother, Jessica Curry, in an Instagram post. (üì∏: Simon and Schuster, Ben Hines)

Food containers made of polystyrene ‚Äî aka Styrofoam ‚Äî will officially be banned from businesses in Maine after Gov. Janet Mills signed a bill into law Tuesday. The law, which will go into effect in 2021, prohibits restaurants, caterers, coffee shops and grocery stores from using the to-go foam containers because they cannot be recycled in the state. More than 256 million pieces of disposable foam cups, plates, bowls, platters, and trays are used every year in Maine, the Natural Resources Council of Maine. For more climate news, follow @cnnclimate. (üì∏: Getty Images)

The rate of suicide among US boys ages 10 to 17 surged in the month after the Netflix show ‚Äú13 Reasons Why‚Äù premiered in March 2017, according to a new study. The nine months after the release saw an extra 195 deaths by suicide among 10- to 17-year-olds than would have otherwise been expected, according to the study published Monday by the Journal of the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry. "This is a critically important topic and we have worked hard to ensure that we handle this sensitive issue responsibly,‚Äù Netflix said Tuesday. (üì∏: Beth Dubber/Netflix)

Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaido made his boldest attempt yet to seize power from President Nicolas Maduro on Tuesday morning, announcing an uprising alongside a group of soldiers in the capital Caracas. His call brought protesters to the city's La Carlota military airbase, where confrontations ensued between Guaido's military supporters and Maduro regime loyalists under a cloud of tear gas. Dozens of people were injured, according to a local hospital. The clashes follow months of demonstrations and unrest in the country that is facing a cratering economy, food and medical supply shortages, and is seeing tens of thousands of its people flee. (üì∏: Frederico Parra, Bloomberg, Picture Alliance, Yuri Cortez, NurPhoto, Getty Images)

The northwest sector of the Ross Ice Shelf in Antarctica, which in total is roughly the size of France, is melting far faster than scientists previously thought, according to the University of Cambridge. Scientists have discovered that ocean water warmed by the sun is partly to blame. The collapse of the world's major ice shelves could lead to a sea level rise of several meters or more, according to the British Antarctic Survey. For more climate news, follow @cnnclimate. (üì∏: Deagostini/Getty Images)

Japan‚Äôs Emperor Akihito formally abdicated Tuesday during a historic ceremony in Tokyo, becoming the country‚Äôs first monarch to step down from the Chrysanthemum Throne in two centuries. Akihito‚Äôs reign officially ended at midnight on Tuesday, and his son was expected to be inaugurated as the 126th emperor on Wednesday. The 85-year-old ruler said he performed his duties as the emperor with a ‚Äúdeep sense of trust and respect‚Äù for the Japanese people. ‚ÄúI consider myself most fortunate to have been able to do so,‚Äù he said at the small abdication ceremony. (üì∏: Kazuhiro Nogi/Getty Images)

An emotional chance encounter at a baseball game brought together a heart transplant recipient and the donor's family ‚ù§Ô∏è On Sunday, which was Transplant Awareness Day at the St. Louis Cardinals game, Donovan Bulger's siblings wore shirts with his photo and the words: "brother, organ donor and hero." Bulger died in 2016 at the age of 21. The man who received Bulger's heart, John Sueme, was also at the game. When Sueme's family recognized Bulger's photo on the shirts, the two families met for the first time. The group hugged and cried, and one by one Bulger's siblings listened to Sueme's heartbeat.
(üì∏: Savannah Roesch)

A fire on Sunday evening ripped through a forest in England that provided the setting for the Winnie the Pooh children‚Äôs stories. The blaze at Ashdown Forest, which was under control Monday morning, affected an area of more than 35 acres, according to local fire authorities. The cause of the blaze was unknown. Author A.A. Milne, who lived nearby, drew inspiration from the forest to write the popular series of children‚Äôs books in the 1920s. (üì∏: Gareth Fuller/AP)

For the first time ever, a model is wearing a burkini and hijab in the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue. For the first time ever, the US renewable energy sector is projected to generate more electricity than coal during the month of April, according to a recent report. Coal, long the king of the power sector, has already been dethroned by natural gas, a cleaner burning fossil fuel. Now, coal is facing intensifying pressure from wind and solar power. "Five years ago this never would have been close to happening,‚Äù said one research analyst. "The transition that's going on in the electric sector in the United States has been phenomenal." For more, go follow @cnnclimate.

"I stand before my family, friends and graduating class today, to say that I am proud to be a gay son of God,‚Äù said Matt Easton in his graduation speech to the class of 2019 at Brigham Young University, a Mormon school.  Easton said later that he felt it was ‚Äúimportant to share both for myself and the LGBTQ+ community at BYU." The university's policy states that "homosexual behavior is inappropriate and violates the Honor Code." (üì∏: Courtesy Matt Easton/Instagram)

The new "Avengers" movie just obliterated box office records, making it the biggest global opening in film history, according to Disney üé¨üí∞ It is the only film to cross the $1 billion mark in its debut weekend. The previous record was held by the film's prequel "Avengers: Infinity War," which made $640 million during its opening last year. #AvengersEndgame wrapped up storylines that have been 22 films in the making. @Avengers
(üì∏: Marvel Studios)

Almost $947 million has been donated to help rebuild Notre Dame after a fire tore through the Paris cathedral earlier this month ‚Äì and about $4 of that came from Caitlyn Handley. The 9-year-old sent her donation by mail with a handwritten note to one of the French charities tasked with collecting donations. "I heard about the Notre Dame fire on the radio and wanted to help, I know it's not much, but every bit helps. Hopefully it won't take too long to build. Thanks, Caitlyn,‚Äù she wrote. (üì∏: Fondation du Patrimoine)

On Sunday, the London Marathon will become the first major race to dole out eco-friendly edible water pods instead of plastic bottles for a portion of the event. The Ooho seaweed capsules, which runners will be given at mile 23, are filled with water and biodegrade within six weeks if they're not eaten ‚Äî a far cry from the 450 or more years it takes a plastic bottle to decompose. For more, go follow @cnnclimate. (üì∏: Charlie Crownhurst/Getty Images)

They‚Äôre cute, they‚Äôre fluffy, and they‚Äôre public enemy No.1 in Australia. The country is at war with feral cats, whose population has ballooned since they were introduced by Europeans sometime in the 17th century. Since then, free-roaming cats have helped drive an estimated 20 mammal species to extinction, making them the single biggest threat to Australia‚Äôs native species, one official told the Sydney Morning Herald. The plan has come under fire from conservationists, who say the killing needs to be more targeted, and from animal rights groups. (üì∏: Iakovos Hatzistavrov/AFP/Getty Images)

This massive $13.6 billion solar energy park in the UAE could eventually power up to 1.3 million homes. The Mohammed Bin Rashid Al Maktoum Solar Park, located deep in Dubai‚Äôs desert, is expected to be the largest single-site solar park in the world when it‚Äôs finished in 2030, and could reduce carbon emissions by 6.5 million tons annually, according to the Dubai Energy and Water Authority. For more, go follow @cnnclimate and @cnnbusiness. (üì∏: Masdar)

A rare baby rhino ü¶è was born at a zoo in Miami on Tuesday, making history as the world‚Äôs first successful rhinoceros birth from induced ovulation and artificial insemination, according to Zoo Miami. This is a big win for conservation ‚Äî there are around 3,500 Indian rhinos left in the world, according to the International Rhino Foundation. (üì∏: Zoo Miami)

‚ÄúAvengers: Endgame‚Äù made $60 million at the US box office for its preview showings on Thursday night. That's the biggest domestic opening night ever, surpassing the record held by another Disney property, ‚ÄúStar Wars: The Force Awakens,‚Äù which made $57 million on its opening night in 2015, according to Comscore. (üì∏: Marvel Studios)

Recurring storms in Antarctica's Weddell Sea have ravaged the population of emperor penguins that live there, destroying the sea ice that penguins need in order to breed, according to a new study. Emperor penguins in the area have failed to raise chicks for the past three years. "It is impossible to say whether the changes in sea-ice conditions at Halley Bay are specifically related to climate change, but such a complete failure to breed successfully is unprecedented at this site,‚Äù said one author of the study. For more, go follow @cnnclimate. (üì∏: Wolfgang Kaehler/Lightrocket/Getty Images)

Antoinette Love, a high school senior in New Orleans, has a difficult decision ahead of her. She says she has no idea what school she‚Äôll attend yet, but she‚Äôs considering Louisiana State University, Valparaiso University and Brandeis University, among others. (üì∏: Courtesy Antoinette Love)

Environmental activist group Extinction Rebellion glued themselves across the front and back entrance of the London Stock Exchange on Thursday, as #climatechange protests continued in the British capital. ‚ÄúGame of Thrones‚Äù star Sophie Turner says criticism of her role as Sansa Stark on the HBO hit series was one of the reasons that led to her depression. ‚ÄúThe biggest challenge is just for me getting out of bed and getting out of the house and learning to love yourself,‚Äù the 23-year-old said. A devastating fire may have gutted Notre Dame in Paris ‚Äî but amid the smoke and ash, the cathedral‚Äôs altar and cross are still intact. As their church burned, members of the Greater Union Baptist Church stood outside, linked arms, and prayed. This 20-year-old woman raising all five of her younger siblings just received a huge gift from the suburban Orlando sheriff‚Äôs office: a brand-new car üöó For the past three years, Samantha Rodriquez (second from right) has been in charge of feeding and clothing her siblings, now ages 5 to 17, following their parents‚Äô deaths. Serious cases of Candida auris infections have been reported in more than 30 countries, including the US, Australia, Germany, and India. The drug-resistant fungus is difficult to diagnose and treat, and typically spreads in hospitals or other health care facilities. "It's a bit of a paradox, really," said Dr. David Eyre, an infectious disease physician based at Oxford University. "Why has it suddenly come to cause a problem at a similar time in different parts of the world?" The Centers for Disease Control and prevention estimate that some 30%-60% of people with C. auris infections have died. (üì∏: US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention)

The largest known minor planet in our solar system has gone nameless for the past decade since it was discovered, known only as 2007 OR10 üååThe three astronomers who discovered it want your help to change that. India, the world‚Äôs largest democracy, kicked off the first of several phases of its national election on Thursday, with right-wing Hindu nationalist Prime Minister Narendra Modi seeking a second term in office. (üì∏: Biju Boro/AFP/Getty Image, Noah Seelam/AFP/Getty Images and Prakash Singh/AFP/Getty Images)

WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has been arrested at the Ecuadorian embassy in London. UK police went into the embassy, where Assange has been living for the past seven years, to detain him for ‚Äúfailing to surrender to the court‚Äù over a warrant issued in 2012. The Australian whistleblower has been holed up at the embassy since 2012, when he was granted asylum as part of a bid to avoid extradition to Sweden, where he was facing allegations of sexual assault. South Korea‚Äôs 66-year abortion ban must be lifted by the end of 2020, the country‚Äôs Constitutional Court has ruled. Seven out of nine judges ruled that outlawing abortion was unconstitutional -- votes from six judges were needed to overturn the ban. Previously, women who had abortions in South Korea could face up to a year in prison and be fined up to two million won ($1,780), while doctors who helped terminate pregnancy could be jailed for up to two years. Abortion was criminalized in South Korea in 1953, with exceptions for rape, incest and genetic disability. Termination of pregnancies after 20 weeks will remain illegal. (üì∏: Ed Jones/AFP/Getty)

Kim Kardashian West said in a recent interview with Vogue that she is hoping to take the California bar exam as early as 2022, and that she began a four-year apprenticeship with a San Francisco law firm last summer in order to prepare. New Zealand's parliament voted almost unanimously in favor of changing the country‚Äôs gun laws, a move that will ban military-style semi-automatic weapons. For the first time in history, scientists have captured an image of a black hole. "We have seen what we thought was unseeable," said the director of the team of scientists. "We have seen and taken a picture of a black hole." The effort began in 2017, using a global network of telescopes to capture the image, according to researchers at the National Science Foundation. Black holes are made up of huge amounts of matter squeezed into a small area, according to NASA, creating a massive gravitational field which draws in everything around it, including light. (üì∏: National Science Foundation)

Yep, you read that right. This man‚Äôs one-way ticket ended up being a one-passenger flight. The last time carbon dioxide levels were this high, Greenland was mostly green, sea levels were up to 20 meters higher and trees grew on Antarctica, according to scientists who warned this week that there is more CO2 in our atmosphere today than in the past 3 million years. Can you believe? UK lawmakers rejected Theresa May‚Äôs Brexit deal for a third time on Friday, likely killing it off for good and plunging the country further into political uncertainty. Yale just became the first school to rescind the admission of a student who was admitted as part of a nationwide college admissions scandal, according to the university. Did you see it? The biggest and brightest supermoon üåï of 2019. George Mendonsa, identified as the sailor in the famous Times Square photo dubbed ‚ÄúThe Kiss,‚Äù has died at age 95. The day after Valentine‚Äôs Day, Terra Pinkard received a text message from the love of her life, Josh Pinkard: "I love you, I've been shot at work," it read. ‚ÄúIt took me several times reading it for it to hit me that it was for real,‚Äù Pinkard wrote in a Facebook post on Sunday. Belize‚Äôs Great Blue Hole was one of the most mysterious places on the planet until Erika Bergman and her team of scientists dove into its depths last month. ‚ÄúYou lose all of that Caribbean sunlight and it just turns completely black‚Ä¶with absolutely no life,‚Äù Bergman said. That‚Äôs right ‚Äî in a last-ditch effort to save his waning community, the mayor of Borgomezzavalle says his town will pay people just over $1,000 per newborn üë∂üèª in an effort to revitalize a population that‚Äôs dwindled to barely 320 residents. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to put into words how much I‚Äôm hurting,‚Äù said Kelsey Friend, a former Marjory Stoneman Douglas student who survived last year‚Äôs school shooting that left 17 people dead. ‚ÄúRest well, rover. Your mission is complete.‚Äù After months of failed efforts to revive communications with NASA‚Äôs Mars rover Opportunity, scientists announced Wednesday that its record-breaking mission had officially ended. ‚ÄúOppy,‚Äù as the rover is affectionately known, far outlasted its original 90-day mission: the robot landed on Mars in 2004 and proceeded to explore the planet‚Äôs surface for 15 years, sending back data and more than 200,000 photos, including some of those pictured above. Soon after it arrived, Opportunity made the breakthrough discovery that water once flowed on the Red Planet‚Äôs surface ‚Äî signaling the conditions for life once existed there. ‚ÄúWhatever loss we feel now must be tempered with the knowledge that the legacy of Opportunity continues,‚Äù said Thomas Zurbuchen, associate administrator for NASA's Science Mission Directorate. (üì∏: NASA)

Murtaza Ahmadi, now 7 years old, became famous in 2016 with this photo showing him in a makeshift Lionel Messi jersey made from a blue-and-white-striped plastic bag. Nearly a year after the photo went viral, Murtaza got to meet the global soccer superstar. Now, the Afghan boy's fame has made him a Taliban target. The elusive African black leopard is alive and well and living in Kenya -- and there are new pictures to prove it. A team of biologists shot rare footage of the sleek big cat after spending months watching and waiting, said Nick Pilfold, a global conservation scientist at the San Diego Zoo. While there have been previous reports of sightings of black leopards in Africa ‚Äì they‚Äôre also known as black panthers ‚Äì the new images offer important confirmation. ‚ÄúIt is likely that black leopards have been living in Kenya all along, it is only that high-quality imagery to confirm it has been missing until now,‚Äù said Pilfold. Take a peek at Barbie‚Äôs new look: In June, Mattel will release a doll with a prosthetic leg and another that comes with a wheelchair. Name a more iconic trio üëë Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, arrives with her husband Prince Harry at the National History Museum for a gala on Tuesday night in London. The couple is expecting their first child. (üì∏: Samir Hussein/WireImage)

BREAKING: Mexican drug lord Joaquin ‚ÄúEl Chapo‚Äù Guzm√°n was found guilty in a US federal court on Tuesday of all 10 federal criminal counts against him, including the top charge of engaging in a continuing criminal enterprise, as well as conspiracy to launder narcotics proceeds, international distribution of cocaine, heroin, marijuana and other drugs. ‚ÄúI am absolutely in favor of legalizing marijuana. We‚Äôve got to do it,‚Äù Democratic Sen. Kamala Harris said on Monday on the New York-based radio show ‚ÄúThe Breakfast Club.‚Äù Co-host Charlamagne Tha God also asked the former California attorney general and current 2020 contender whether she had smoked marijuana. ‚ÄúI have. ‚ÄúI am burned out,‚Äù said one Denver teacher who works four jobs. The Mile-High City has become so expensive that teachers are forced to get creative to make ends meet: Most bunk with roommates, some wait tables, drive for ride-sharing companies, and one told CNN that he‚Äôs taken out loans to pay for a new apartment‚Äôs security deposit and first month‚Äôs rent. The teachers and Denver Public Schools have been negotiating for over a year to overhaul the district‚Äôs compensation system, to no avail. So on Monday, for the first time in 25 years, Denver teachers went on strike. (üì∏: Kelsey Brown, Kevlyn Walsh)

Alicia Keys was the first woman to host the #Grammys in 14 years üéπüé§üé∂ During Sunday night's show, the 15-time Grammy winner played two pianos at the same time. It's a polar bear invasion. Parents in a remote Russian archipelago are scared to send their children to school after a "mass invasion" of polar bears into residential areas, state news agency TASS reported. A state of emergency was announced on Saturday, with up to 10 polar bears reportedly on the settlement's territory at any given time. Polar bears are increasingly coming into contact with humans as climate change reduces their sea-ice habitats, forcing them on land for longer periods of time.
(üì∏: @friend__of__your__friend/Instagram)

Childish Gambino's "This Is America" won Grammys for song and record of the year on Sunday, becoming the first rap song to win the prestigious awards. "This Is America" beat out "Shallow," "God's Plan" and other big hits. #Grammys
(üì∏: Donald Glover)

‚ÄúMusic helps us share ourselves. Our dignities, our sorrows, our hopes and joys. It allows us to hear one another, to invite each other in,‚Äù Michelle Obama said during a surprise appearance at the 61st annual #GRAMMYs on Sunday in Los Angeles. The former first lady appeared alongside Lady Gaga, Jada Pinkett Smith, Jennifer Lopez and host Alicia Keys. (üì∏: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for The Recording Academy)

In the remnants of wildfire-scarred homes and burned-out cars, an artist is paying tribute to the town of Paradise, California, which was devastated by last summer‚Äôs Camp Fire. The artist, Shane Grammer, grew up near Paradise and said the idea for the project formed after he saw images of the devastation on Facebook. Another byproduct of this extreme cold weather of 2019 ‚ùÑÔ∏è ghost apples‚Äù üëªüçé These ‚Äúghost apples‚Äù were spotted in Michigan after freezing rain moved through the area recently. The farmer who snapped these photos suspected that the ethereal phenomenon occurred because it was cold enough that the ice encasing the fruit remained frozen, but warm enough that the apple inside turned to complete mush. ‚ÄúWhen I pruned a tree it would be shaken in the process, and the mush would slip out of the bottom of the ‚Äòghost apple.‚Äô‚Äù (üì∏: Andrew Sietsema)

The largest shipment of meth ever was confiscated by US authorities in California. The 1.7 tons of methamphetamine was worth nearly a billion dollars and initially bound for Australia. It was hidden inside electronics equipment along with smaller amounts of cocaine and heroin and at least six people were arrested, police said. (üì∏: Australian Federal Police)

At the age of 97, style luminary Iris Apfel just signed a major modeling contract with global agency IMG, which also represents supermodels such as Karlie Kloss, Chrissy Teigen and Bella and Gigi Hadid. Apfel started her career as an interior designer and won fame for her eclectic personal style, including her trademark oversize glasses and penchant for bold colors. I think retirement is a fate worse than death,‚Äù she told Women‚Äôs Wear Daily. (üì∏: Courtesy Landmark Hong Kong)

This newly formed island in the South Pacific has left the scientists who discovered it scratching their heads. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very sticky,‚Äù said one scientist. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm still a little baffled of where it‚Äôs coming from. Because it‚Äôs not ash.‚Äù The island, which is covered in vegetation and a mysterious mud, was formed by volcanic eruption in 2014. (üì∏: NASA)

In an unprecedented move, the princess of Thailand entered the race to be the country‚Äôs next prime minister on Friday. Princess Ubolratana Rajakanya, whose brother is the king, will run for the Thai Raksa Chart Party, which is aligned with a populist former prime minister who was ousted by the military in a 2005 coup. No close member of the royal family has run for prime minister in Thailand since the era of the absolute monarch ended 86 years ago. ‚ÄúI think that it‚Äôs part of a plan by the current sovereign to increase his personal power across the country,‚Äù said one politics expert at Thailand‚Äôs Naresuan University. (üì∏: Kristian Dowling/Getty Images)

A mom held a heartwarming gender reveal party for her transgender 20-year-old son. There were blue balloons, blue confetti and a big teddy bear. Last September Adrian Brown began his transition. His mom said she didn't just want to support the journey; she wanted to celebrate it. "It breaks my heart that not everyone gets the support that I do," Brown told CNN. He said he's heard thousands of stories of people who were inspired by the shoot.
(üì∏: Heather Lundberg Brown)

Venezuela's government blocked this bridge to prevent humanitarian aid from getting into the country, which desperately needs food and medical supplies. ‚ÄúWe are not beggars,‚Äù said President Nicolas Maduro. Self-declared president Juan Guaido is fighting to get the aid in. "We will succeed in letting the humanitarian aid in, because it's about saving lives," Guaido tweeted Thursday. (üì∏: Edinson Estupinan/AFP/Getty Images) (This copy has been updated.)

Consider it the 2020 corridor üá∫üá∏üöù Longtime Amtrak traveler and former Vice President Joe Biden ran into a familiar face on the train Thursday: Sen. Kamala Harris of California. This was a casual enough encounter, but one day, the two may meet in the Democratic primary ‚Äî if Biden decides to run. Harris announced she would run for president last month. (üì∏: Maya Harris, Kirsten Allen)

Thousands of flamingo chicks have been rescued from a dried-out South African dam after their parents abandoned them. Around 2,000 chicks were airlifted to safety from the Kamfers Dam at the end of January, after a significant drop in the dam‚Äôs water levels. It was brought on by drought conditions in the northern Cape -- South Africa has been struggling with water shortages in recent years. "These chicks arrived in a very bad condition since a lot of them were dehydrated, they were tiny -- some of them were just coming out of their eggs -- so we had a little bit of a problem with infections,‚Äù an organisation helping to care for the birds said. (üì∏: Rodger Bosch/AFP/Getty Images)

A 20-foot-tall wooden cross washed up in front of a beachside tiki bar in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, last weekend, prompting beachgoers to speculate about where it came from. Frank Talerico, the owner of nearby Ocean Manor Beach Resort, said he believes the cross is a sign from God. This 10-year-old Cub Scout took a knee during the Pledge of Allegiance at a city council meeting in Durham, North Carolina, invoking the protest made popular by former San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick. ‚ÄúWhat I did was took a knee against racial discrimination, which is basically when people are mean to other people of different colors,‚Äù Liam Holmes told CNN affiliate WNCN. (üì∏: WNCN, father handout)

Last year was the fourth-hottest year ever recorded, according to the National Oceanic and atmospheric Administration and NASA, which means that the past five years have been the five warmest years in the modern record. The average global temperature has risen about 2 degrees Fahrenheit since the 1880s.‚ÄúThis warming has been driven in large part by increased emissions into the atmosphere of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases caused by human activities,‚Äù said Gavin Schmidt, director of NASA‚Äôs Goddard Institute for Space Studies. (üì∏: Tao Zhang/Getty Images)

Women now hold 32 of the 63 seats in the Nevada legislature, making the body 50.8% female‚Äîa first for the state and the US. The female lawmakers got together for a group photo Monday before the legislature convened for its first session. ‚ÄúOur foremothers...along with scores of dozens of other female legislators, have cleared a path for us. A path that we will now walk,‚Äù said Democratic Assembly Majority Leader Teresa Benitez-Thompson to CNN affiliate KOLO. ‚ÄúWe will make this state and our nation proud.‚Äù (üì∏: Cathleen Allison/Nevada Momentum)

President Donald Trump delivered an hour and 20-minute State of the Union speech in which he appealed to lawmakers' sense of unity at a moment of deepening partisan spite. His calls for conciliation -- which did not address his role in inflaming partisan divisions -- were met with mostly stone-faced silence from Democrats.

Delivering the Democratic response, former Georgia gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams blamed the Trump administration for the longest government shutdown in US history, saying it was a stunt engineered by the President. ‚†Ä‚†Ä ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
During the speech, Trump singled out honored guests including Alice Marie Johnson, a former inmate who was granted clemency by Trump last year. Johnson, whose case garnered support from Kim Kardashian West and others, was moved to tears as the chamber gave her a standing ovation.

There have never been as many women serving in Congress as there are today. At Tuesday's #SOTU, they‚Äôre hoping to send a message, ‚Äúwearing suffragette white is a respectful message of solidarity with women across the country, and a declaration that we will not go back on our hard-earned rights," said Rep. Lois Frankel, the chair of the House Democratic Women's Working Group. By wearing white in solidarity, the women are honoring the women's suffrage movement and women's rights.
(üì∏: Tom Williams/Sipa USA, Saul Loeb/AFP/Getty Images and Alex Brandon/AP)

Pope Francis has become the first pontiff to deliver mass in the Arabian Peninsula, the birthplace of Islam. The mass, delivered in front of some 135,000 attendees at Zayed Sports City stadium in Abu Dhabi on Tuesday, comes as a highlight of the pope's historic visit to the United Arab Emirates. The ceremony began inside the stadium as a large crucifix, a rare sight in an Arab Gulf state, loomed above the makeshift steeple. (üì∑ KARIM SAHIB, GIUSEPPE CACACE, VINCENZO PINTO, FRANCOIS NEL, AFP/Getty Images)

At least a third of the ice in the Hindu Kush Himalaya region, an area that includes Mount Everest and K2, will probably thaw by the end of this century, according to an assessment released Monday ‚Äî even if there is aggressive action to curb greenhouse gases and meet the goals of the Paris climate agreement. Glaciers in the region have been shrinking since the 1970s, and this loss has caused severe economic damage, floods, landslides and deadly epidemics. ‚ÄúThe consequences are pretty extreme. We are concerned, and we are worried,‚Äù said one of the report‚Äôs authors. ‚ÄúUrgent climate action is needed.‚Äù (üì∏: Prakash Mathema/AFP/Getty Images)

Rapper 21 Savage, whose musical persona revolves around the gang life he purportedly weathered growing up in Atlanta, was arrested Sunday by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement. The agency says the Grammy-nominated musician, whose birth name is She‚Äôyaa Bin Abraham-Joseph, is a U.K. citizen who overstayed his visa which expired in 2006. He is now facing deportation. (üì∏:Roy Rochlin/Getty Images)

Once again, the New England Patriots are Super Bowl champions, beating the Los Angeles Rams 13-3 at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta. With the win, the Patriots are tied with the Pittsburgh Steelers for the most Super Bowl titles in NFL history, and quarterback Tom Brady now has won more Super Bowls than any other player. Brady was 21-for-35 passing for 262 yards, and most of those yards went to wide receiver Julian Edelman, who was named the game's MVP. But the pacing of the game frustrated some viewers ‚Äî it was the first Super Bowl without a touchdown through the first three quarters. It also was the fewest points in a Super Bowl for both teams combined and the fewest by the winning team. Photos: Jamie Squire/Maddie Meyer/Angela Weiss/Mike Ehrmann/Rob Carr/Getty Images

This vending machine isn‚Äôt dispensing sugary treats, fatty chips or high-calorie sodas. It‚Äôs dropping knowledge. An elementary school in Umatilla, Florida, unveiled the machine, which contains books üìö with a variety of reading-skill levels, as part of the state‚Äôs literacy week. When students are kind, get their homework done, or simply make good choices, they are rewarded with ‚ÄúBulldog Bucks,‚Äù which they can use to select a book at the vending machine. (üì∏: Umatilla Elementary School)

Machu Picchu, the wildly popular tourist destination in the Peruvian Andes, is now wheelchair accessible. The travel company ‚ÄúWheel the World‚Äù developed the first-ever wheelchair accessible tour of the famous Inca ruins. The company was founded by two best friends ‚Äî one who uses a wheelchair one who doesn‚Äôt ‚Äî and aims to help people in wheelchairs travel to hard-to-get-to places. (üì∏: Justin Setterfield/Getty Images)

A hotel in China‚Äôs Zhejiang province unveiled a hot spring pool designed to look like a giant Chinese hot pot, complete with produce such as limes, chilies and apples. Hangzhou‚Äôs First World Hotel, which is a two-hour drive from Shanghai, says it wants to promote a healthy lifestyle in the run-up to the Lunar New Year, or spring festival, which begins the first week of February. (üì∏:STR/AFP/Getty Images)

Stargazers in the UK got a treat Tuesday morning after Venus (far left), Jupiter and the moon ‚≠êüåô‚ú® appeared together in the dawn sky. The event, which is called a conjunction, is fairly common, but the clear conditions on Tuesday made the phenomenon more dazzling than usual. (üì∏: Rebecca Weir)

Captain Rosemary Mariner, the first woman to fly a tactical fighter jet in the US Navy, will receive the first-ever all-female flyover at her funeral on Saturday. Mariner, pictured above in the 1990s, died January 24 after a long battle with ovarian cancer. She was 65. Mariner was the Navy's first female jet pilot and the "first female military aviator to achieve command of an operational air squadron," according to a Navy statement. (üì∏: US Navy/University of Tennessee)

This Kurdish-Iranian asylum seeker won Australia‚Äôs top literary prize for a book he wrote via text message inside a refugee camp in Papua New Guinea. Behrouz Boochani couldn‚Äôt attend Thursday‚Äôs ceremony where he nabbed the Victorian Prize for Literature and the Non-Fiction Prize, which in total netted him about $90,000. The award committee described his book, ‚ÄúNo Friends But the Mountains: Writing from Manus Prison,‚Äù as a ‚Äúvoice of witness, an act of survival. A lyric first-hand account. A cry of resistance. A vivid portrait through five years of incarceration and exile.‚Äù (üì∏: Behrouz Boochani)

A massive hole two-thirds the size of Manhattan has been discovered growing in an Antarctic glacier, signaling rapid ice decay that has shocked scientists. The cavity ‚Äî measuring almost 1,000 feet tall ‚Äî is big enough to have contained 14 billion tons of ice, and ‚Äúmost of that ice melted over the last three years,‚Äù NASA said. (üì∏: NASA/OIB/Jeremy Harbeck)

Despite bitter cold temperatures on Thursday, the Old Guard was on duty outside the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia. The guard is changed every hour when the cemetery is open, Major Stephen Von Jett said. ‚ÄúOur Soldiers have great cold weather equipment that allows them to brave these conditions, but it‚Äôs their commitment to the mission, and to representing the US Army‚Äôs commitment to the American people that keeps their backs straight against the wind.‚Äù (üì∏: The Old Guard)

It‚Äôs extremely cold in Wisconsin, but that didn‚Äôt stop firefighters in Cameron from showing up to work Wednesday. Fire Department Chief Mitch Hansen, above, battled fire and ice as temperatures in the area dipped to about 50 degrees below zero with wind chill. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre a small team of volunteers but we‚Äôre careful and trained,‚Äù said another firefighter, who snapped the photo Hansen after they contained a blaze that destroyed a home. ‚ÄúWhen it‚Äôs that cold you just can‚Äôt move.‚Äù (üì∏: Courtesy Bimbo Gifford)

Ruby Kate Chitsey, an 11-year-old from Harrison, Arkansas, was visiting the nursing home where mom worked when she noticed that many of the residents there said they couldn‚Äôt afford simple pleasures like fresh fruit or books. So Ruby Kate and her mom decided to help. The two launched a GoFundMe, ‚ÄúThree Wishes for Ruby‚Äôs Residents,‚Äù which had raised almost $70,000 as of Thursday morning. (üì∏: Courtesy Beth Ann Crenshaw)

This village in Kenya is run by and for women only. Founded by 15 rape survivors in 1990, Umoja, which means ‚Äúunity‚Äù in Swahili, is a refuge for women seeking to escape abusive marriages, rape and other forms of assault. The 48 women who live there now are all of the Samburu culture, which is a deeply patriarchal society that practices female genital mutilation, believes in polygamy and is against educating women. ‚ÄúIf I had not come here, I don‚Äôt know what my life would be,‚Äù said one woman, who was brought to Umoja as a child. "These women raised me, allowed me to have an education and defied all those traditions.‚Äù (üì∏: Faith Karimi/CNN)

Officials are warning of almost instant frostbite as temperatures plunge below zero across large swaths of the US on Wednesday. If you're among the more than 80 million people in the US facing subzero temperatures ‚Äî the "coldest air in a generation," experts say ‚Äî avoid going outside unless absolutely necessary, and if you do, bundle up.
(üì∏: David Joles/Star Tribune/AP)

Actor Jussie Smollett, who stars in the series ‚ÄúEmpire,‚Äù was attacked early Tuesday in Chicago by two assailants who yelled racial and homophobic slurs, put a rope around his neck and doused him with an unknown chemical substance, police said. The attack is being investigated as a hate crime. Smollett took himself to a nearby hospital and is in good condition, according to police. (üì∏: Tesla Wells/Getty Images)

These firefighters in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, were dispatched along with EMTs when a woman went into labor in her living room. After the baby, Scotty Jr., arrived, first responders brought the mother and newborn out to transfer them to the hospital. Outside, they found firefighters who stayed behind to shovel the family‚Äôs snowy driveway. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the little things that touch you in a moment like that,‚Äù said a family member. (üì∏: Larissa Ruffin)

A tornado ripped through Havana, Cuba, on Sunday night, killing at least three people and injuring more than 172. Strong winds damaged buildings and caused flooding in low-lying areas of capital, the Cuban government said. Much of the city was left without electricity.
(üì∏: @cubareporter)

This Sunday, Quinton Peron and Napoleon Jinnies will cheer for the Los Angeles Rams alongside their female counterparts as they take on the the New England Patriots in Super Bowl LIII in Atlanta. Peron and Jinnies already made history in March, when they ‚Äî along with Jesse Hernandez of the New Orleans Saints ‚Äî became the first male cheerleaders in NFL history.
(üì∏: Harry How/Getty Images)

CNN went undercover in Venezuela, where hunger and the threat of starvation are growing as the nation's two competing presidents remain locked in a battle for control of the government. "People are killing each other for a kilo of rice, or flour, or water," said one Venezuelan. "This isn't political, it's survival." In one Caracas supermarket last week, there were no eggs or bread. A modest basket of water, nuts, cheese, ham and fruit cost about $200.
(üì∏: Federico Parra/AFP/Getty Images and Marco Bello/Getty Images)

‚ÄúBlack Panther‚Äù won big at the SAG Awards. The cast of the superhero mega-hit took home the top award for outstanding performance by an ensemble in a motion picture at the 25th Screen Actors Guild Awards on Sunday. Above, stars Angela Basset, Lupita Nyong‚Äôo and Danai Gurira. (üì∏: JEAN-BAPTISTE LACROIX/AFP/AFP/Getty Images)

Martin Luther King Jr.‚Äôs house will soon be open to the public after the National Park Foundation purchased it earlier this month. The home in the Vine City neighborhood in Atlanta is where the civil rights leader and his wife, Coretta Scott King, raised their children. Their daughter Bernice A. King said the family lived there when her father was assassinated in 1968. ‚ÄúMy brothers and I are honored to have fulfilled my mother‚Äôs wish to allow future generations to know the story of our dad as a father, a husband, a minister, and a civil rights leader,‚Äù she said. (üì∏: National Park Service)

These women had never met, lived on opposite coasts, and didn't know the other existed. Then they found out they were twin sisters. That revelation began when Michele Mordkoff (right), inspired by CNN Films' ‚ÄúThree Identical Strangers,‚Äù decided to take a DNA test, which showed that she had an ‚Äúimmediate family member‚Äù whom she'd never met. Just a few weeks later, Mordkoff came face to face with her long lost twin, Allison Kanter, in New York, after more than 50 years apart. The two had been separated when they were 5 months old. ‚ÄúI wanted to hug her, and tell her that I hope she‚Äôs OK and that life was good for her,‚Äù said Mordkoff. (üì∏: Family Photo)

An Indiana school superintendent was charged with insurance fraud after pretending a sick student was her son so she could get him treatment. Court documents allege that Casey Smitherman used her son‚Äôs insurance when she was unable to get a treatment for another boy, a 15-year-old student who was suffering with a sore throat. ‚ÄúI am committed to this community and our students, and I regret if this action has undermined your trust in me,‚Äù Smitherman said. In an emotional press conference ahead of the Australian Open, British tennis great Andy Murray announced that he plans to retire at Wimbledon -- at the latest -- due to ongoing pain in his surgically repaired right hip. The newly sworn-in Congress is the most diverse in US history. Meet some of the freshman lawmakers who broke down race and gender barriers.

From top left:

Rep. Sylvia Garcia is one of the first Latinas from Texas to serve in Congress.

Rep. Ayanna Pressley is the first black congresswoman to represent Massachusetts.

Rep. Jahana Hayes is the first black congresswoman from Connecticut.

Rep. Deb Haaland is one of the first Native American women elected to Congress.

Rep. Veronica Escobar is one of the first Latinas from Texas to serve in Congress.

Rep. Ilhan Omar is the first Somali-American member of Congress and one of the first Muslim women elected to Congress.

Rep. Rashida Tlaib is one of the first Muslim women elected to Congress, and the first Palestinian-American woman to serve.

Sen. Kyrsten Sinema is the first woman elected senator from Arizona.

Rep. Sharice Davids is one of the first Native American women elected to Congress, and the first member from Kansas to identify as LGBTQ.

29-year-old Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is the youngest woman ever elected to Congress.

Sen. Marsha Blackburn is the first female senator from Tennessee.

32-year-old Rep. Lauren Underwood is the youngest black woman ever elected to Congress.

She‚Äôs back. Rep. Nancy Pelosi officially reclaimed the gavel as speaker of the House on Thursday. The California Democrat previously held the title when she served as the first and only female House speaker from 2007 to 2011. Before taking her oath of office, Pelosi acknowledged the record-breaking number of women in Congress: ‚ÄúLet us pray that God may bless our work and crown our good with brotherhood ‚Äî and sisterhood ‚Äî from sea to shining sea.‚Äù (üì∏: Saul Loeb/AFP/Getty Images)

In a historic first, China successfully landed a rover on the far side of the moon, Chinese state media announced on Thursday, and it sent back a close-range image. The spacecraft, named Chang'e 4, landed in the South Pole-Aitken Basin, the moon's largest and oldest impact crater, CCTV reported. The far side of the moon is the hemisphere that never faces earth, due to the moon's rotation. It is sometimes mistakenly referred to as the "dark side of the moon," even though it receives just as much sunlight as its earth-facing side.
(üì∏: AP)

While Joshua Tree will remain open during the partial shutdown, the park service lacks funding for sanitation workers to clean the campgrounds‚Äô pit toilets. Pardon the pixels‚Äîthis is an image of an ice world 4 billion miles away from Earth. (üì∏: NASA)

The Boilermakers weren‚Äôt expected to win, and Trent wasn‚Äôt expected to be there ‚Äî but they did, and he was, according to the newspaper. Trent, who was an honorary captain for Purdue and received the Disney Spirit Ward during ESPN‚Äôs College Football Awards Show, also gave back to his community. In the last few weeks of his life, Trent raised over $100,000 for cancer research during a dance marathon at his alma mater. ‚ÄúThere was no quit in him. There was a lot of fight in him. It‚Äôs like you couldn‚Äôt get him down. While I‚Äôm sure he was in pain and suffering, he put a smile on his face,‚Äù Boilermarkers head coach Jeff Brohm told the Indianapolis Star. Serena Williams and Roger Federer strike a pose after their historic mixed doubles match at the Hopman Cup in Perth. You can see how focused she is and that‚Äôs what I love about her,‚Äù said Federer. (üì∏: Paul Kane/Getty Images)

‚ÄúIn need of a kidney for my wife, B+. 917-442-6202." When Raymond Thompson‚Äôs wife, Mylen, was diagnosed with kidney disease two years ago, she found that none of her family members were a match. So Raymond decided to wear a sign, asking the world for help. Last week, a CNN editor spotted him while shopping at a Target and shared this photo on Twitter, where it went viral. Soon, strangers were calling and texting, offering to give Mylen a kidney. "I appreciate everyone who reaches out. It means a lot to us to get the message out there.‚Äù Thompson said he plans to contact those who've reached out in January. Of the nearly 100,000 people waiting for a kidney last year, only about 20% were able to find a match, according to the United Network of Organ Sharing.

A transformer explosion at a power plant in Queens temporarily lit up the New York City skyline in a brilliant blue on Thursday night. Colin O'Brady just became the first person ever to trek solo across Antarctica, traversing 932 miles in 54 days. The Sydney to Hobart yacht race, a Boxing Day tradition, is officially underway. Fifty years ago, Apollo 8 was credited with "saving" a terrible year. By Christmas Eve in 1968, the Apollo 8 crew ‚Äî Frank Borman, Bill Anders and Jim Lovell ‚Äî had made history. They became the first humans to leave Earth's gravity, orbit the moon and see its far side. Apollo 8 astronaut Bill Anders took this breathtaking photo of the "Earthrise" over the moon's landscape.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
An estimated 1 billion people in 64 countries tuned in as the NASA spacecraft broadcasted live from space. "This is Apollo 8 coming to you live from the moon," Borman announced after activating a small hand-held TV camera. "We are now approaching lunar sunrise and for all the people back on Earth, the crew of Apollo 8 has a message that we would like to send to you. 'In the beginning, God created heaven and Earth. ...'" Each astronaut read a few lines from the Bible's Book of Genesis. The broadcast concluded, "And from the crew of Apollo 8, we close with good night, good luck, a merry Christmas and God bless all of you, all of you on the good Earth."
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
(üì∏: @NASA)

It's beginning to look a lot like Christmas ... again. The National Christmas Tree in Washington has reopened after a brief closure tied to the government shutdown, the National Park Foundation announced on Monday. üéÑThe tree sustained damage after a man climbed it Friday evening and then remained closed because of the shutdown. Opening the tree site costs $1,470 per day, and support from the National Park Service's charitable foundation allowed the site to reopen on Christmas Eve. ‚û°Ô∏è Swipe to see the how the tree looked in the dark on Sunday.

Survivors search through debris at their homes after a tsunami struck the Indonesian coastline without warning Saturday night. Hundreds have died and hundreds more are injured. Eyewitnesses described fleeing for their lives as beachfront homes were swept away in the wave, which is thought to have been caused by underwater landslides following the eruption of the Anak Krakatau volcano. Authorities are warning more deadly tsunamis could strike as the volcano continues to erupt. Indonesian President Joko Widodo ordered the country's meteorology agency to buy detectors that would provide "early warnings to community."
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
(üì∏: Fauzy Chaniago/AP, Ulet Ifansasti/Getty Images and Azwar Ipank/AFP/Getty Images)

Britain‚Äôs Queen Elizabeth II has used her 2018 Christmas message to call for people to show more respect to those with opposing views. "Even with the most deeply held differences, treating the other person with respect and as a fellow human being is always a good first step towards greater understanding," the Queen says in excerpts of the televised address, released by Buckingham Palace on Monday. The 92-year-old monarch also says that the Christian message of "peace on earth and goodwill to all" is timeless, and "needed as much as ever." The message features the Queen sitting at a desk in the White Drawing Room at Buckingham Palace, with a black-and-white photograph of her and her husband Prince Philip with their son Prince Charles as a baby. üì∑: WPA Pool / Getty Images

This year, CNN brought you stories of average people who've found extraordinary ways to help others. We went back to see how some of these determined people are doing.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Last summer, Rodney Smith Jr. set out to voluntary mow 50 lawns in 50 states ‚Äî and help the elderly, the disabled, single moms and veterans along the way. At the start of the holiday season, Smith decided to dress as Santa Claus and surprise homeless people with gifts in every new city he visited.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Four-year-old Austin Perine captured the hearts of fans around the globe as video of him handing out chicken sandwiches to the homeless was shared millions of times on social media. Since CNN aired his story in July, Austin has traveled to over 15 cities to spread his message: #ShowLove.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Teenager Kevin Barber launched a pilot program in San Diego called "Wheels of Change." It pays the homeless $11.50 an hour to clean up the streets. "Workers are so thankful for the opportunity to work... contribute to the community and make a little money to buy their personal items, or buy a bus pass for a job interview," Barber said.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Principal Akbar Cook learned that some students at his Newark, New Jersey, school were chronically absent because they were bullied for their dirty clothes. So, Cook installed washers and dryers for students to use before and after school free of charge. When the news got out, laundry supplies were donated to the school from around the world. And school attendance has improved.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Six days a week, Erica Guido, a suburban mom drives her pickup truck to inner-city Detroit, dropping off donations and spreading good will. She is the president and founder of "To Detroit, With Love." Since the organization started in October 2017, it has helped more than 200 families, and the network of donors has grown to nearly 3,000.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä

"We have taken on some of the biggest challenges of our time, and we have made a great and lasting difference in the trajectory of this country." Leicester City Football Club fans mourned the death of the club's beloved owner, Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha, outside the King Power Stadium in Leicester, eastern England, on Sunday. The Thai billionaire was one of five people on board a helicopter that crashed and burst into flames in a parking lot next to the stadium on Saturday night. In a statement, the club confirmed that nobody survived the crash, and described the chairman as a "a man of kindness, of generosity and a man whose life was defined by the love he devoted to his family and those he so successfully led." Srivaddhanaprabha bought the club for $57 million in 2010, and it was promoted to the Premier League in 2014. In 2016, they achieved the once-unthinkable feat of winning the premiership. Along with handing fans their first top-flight title in the club's history, Srivaddhanaprabha won over fans by handing out free beer, water and cupcakes, as well as scarves in cold weather, in the stands. At Arusha Secondary School in Tanzania girls take a compulsory test twice a year. A pregnancy test. And failure is not an option. If it comes back positive, the student is expelled. In the scene, the girl is turned away from school, her parents, her community and the government. See more details on our Instagram Story. #dayofthegirl #asequals

Lee Keum-seom hasn't held her son in 68 years. The last time she saw him, Sang Chol was four years old, and together with her husband and their daughter, they were headed south, fleeing the fighting during the early days of the Korean War. In the mass of hundreds of thousands of others trying to escape, Lee and her daughter lost sight of her husband and Sang Chol. They continued south, becoming part of the flood of refugees who crossed what became the Demilitarized Zone. Only later did she discover that her husband and son remained on the other side of the divide, in North Korea. They are among the tens of thousands of Koreans whose families were separated by the war -- but today they were able to reunite, as part of government-run family reunions to bring dozens of relatives back together. Before their meeting, Lee Keum-seom had wondered "Will it be okay to hug my son who's over 70 years old?" But in the end, there was no hesitation, and the two elderly Koreans embraced each other tightly, both in tears. During the whole reunion, they did not let go of each others' hands. US Customs and Border Protection has released these images from inside a detention facility for migrant families and unaccompanied children in McAllen, Texas.

The Trump administration has been pursuing a zero-tolerance policy toward illegal border crossings, in which every immigrant arrested for crossing the border is referred for federal prosecution. The policy has had the effect of separating the arrested immigrants from their children. Department of Homeland Security officials say that at least 2,000 children have been separated from their parents since it began implementing the policy in late April.

The border processing center is the first place that detained immigrants go after they are arrested, but the stay is only temporary. Those arrested are then transferred to Department of Justice custody and presented before a judge for the crime of illegal entry into the United States. As part of that process, the immigrant's child or children will be transferred to the US Department of Health and Human Services, Office of Refugee Resettlement.

While CNN was able to tour the facility, Customs and Border Control barred media from shooting any pictures or video, citing privacy concerns.
